title: love island quiz finale 2019
story: Because you’d hardly describe this year’s intake as “lovable”.In fact, with the odd exception , they’ve probably been the most cliquey, manipulative, fork-tongued and spineless bunch so far.The abundance of storylines they’ve produced, though, means Love Island remains a television phenomenon. So let’s not pretend I don’t need the show every bit as much as the Love Islanders deserve the low-grade abuse contained in this quiz, whichtests just how closely you’ve been watching. Answers at foot of page.. Who was Curtis referring to when he said: “You are gorgeous. You are beautul. You are literally a star ”. Complete Maura’s sentence. “I’ve only ever slept with . . . ”. Tommy said: “I believe le’s a test.” But what did he think was “the prize” . What is the name of Tommy and Molly-Mae’s cuddly elephant toy . Who or what was Arabella talking about here  “Downward dog, inhale and I’m into the plank.”. What sex position did Harley tell Chris was her favourite on their very first day as a “couple” . What words appear directly above Caroline Flack’s name in the end credits . Before entering the villa, Anton joked: “I’ve got this serious medical condition.” What was it . Who did Michael describe as “a real-le hero” . Complete Anna’s sentence. “Is it right that no matter where you are in the world, you’re looking at . . . ”. Molly-Mae said: “I feel in a few years’ time we won’t have enough doctors, nurses, dentists. Kids these days don’t want to study.” What does Molly-Mae do for a living . Who did Yewande say she hates watching on television . Joanna laughed: “I’m going into the villa for . . . ”. What does Jourdan think Barcelona is . Who were the first two people to enter the villa . Having told a distressed Amy, “You’re better than that . A proper f***ing joke”, what did Maura do next . What did George do before entering the villa . What fact was Belle astonished to discover about Edinburgh BBC’s This Week has, by and large, been a force for political good since it started in .Yes, it did tend to attract the very worst sort of guests. Out-of-their- depth left-wing comedians , -ton Euro smuggernauts like Benedicte Paviot, the professionally indignant Owen Jones and all those other political trainspotters and obsessive social misfits who make le a slightly bigger ballache than it needs to be for the . per cent of the population who don’t think a day is incomplete without an argument about NHS funding.Every single one of the above, however, got exactly what they deserved on This Week, where they were mercilessly torn to shreds by Andrew Neil, who firmly established himself as television’s greatest political interviewer during its -year history.Unforgettably, it also produced the funniest TV moment of  when an incredibly po-faced Bobby Gillespie, of Primal Scream, refused to join in the Skibidi dance challenge with Neil, Michael Portillo and Caroline Flint MP.So it’s a shame This Week has been axed and I’d hoped the last episode, on Thursday, would give it the smart, brutal, nicely understated send-off this fine show deserved.What it got was Piers Morgan, some fat bloke from thedressed as Danny Zuko from Grease, Portillo dancing around in his pants and a fright wig to Look At Me, I’m Sandra Dee and Mick Hucknall serenading Neil with a chorus of Nobody Does It Better.Yet still some people insist politics is just “showbiz for ugly people”. Nighty-night.Jamie Weir: “Without resorting to cliches, golf is like a religion in Ireland.”And Boris Becker: “If game A doesn’t work, Federer goes to game C. Andthat doesn’t work, game B.”THE Lateish Show, Mo Gilligan to Jessie J: “You’re in a high-profile relationship with Channing Tatum. I saw on Instagram he lost a bet ”CHANNEL ’s beautul, moving and entertaining series Extreme Tribe: The Last Pygmies finished on an uncertain note for the Mbendjele people of the Congo, last night.A road is being built through their jungle home which could bring wealth but also destroy their hunter-gatherer way of le.If that message chilled the bones of millennials, imagine what this next bombshell, dropped by presenter Livia Simoka, did for those of us in the - age bracket.“The Mbendjele people drink palm wine.”In other words, contrary to everything we were told last century, a hippo didn’t take “an apricot, a guava and a mango and do a dainty tango”. Nor did the rhino say, “I know, we’ll call it Um Bongo.”Um Bongo Um Bongo, they don’t drink it in the Congo at all. It was just another neo-colonialist establishment marketing lie.And honestly,you can’t even believe in catchy mid-Eighties advertising jingles any more, what the hell can you believe in This Morning chef Brian Turner: “I don’t know about you, Eamonn, but when we have three chickens for Sunday lunch, there’s always something left over.”Left  Over  Nope, you’ve lost him, Brian.And it’s four chickens.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: inside hamptons mansion beyonce jay z
story: The home, known as Sandcastle, sprawls over three stories and close to  acres with  separate bathrooms, a -foot heated pool, rock-climbing wall and bowling alley.Fit for the celebrity couple, the home in celebrity hot spot Bridgehampton, is billed as the ultimate choice in luxury, relaxation and entertainment.Jay Z and Beyonce reportedly filmed a music video in the lush property grounds, taking their daughter Blue Ivy there in  for her first summer.At that time, the couple paid , for their month-long stay, Forbes reported.And now - depending on the season - holidaygoers can expect to fork out as much as million for their stay.The Bespoke Real Estate listing reads: Indulge in any activity your heart desires in this all-inclusive setting.A recreational pavilion, sunken tennis court with a pergola, ’ x ’ gunite pool with underwater stereo, an oversized hot tub, full outdoor kitchen, basketball court, baseball field and tree house assure something for everyone.The homes grand interior opens up to a magnicent entry hall with elegant bordeaux walnut heated floors, extensive custom millwork, architectural ceilings and high-end finishes.The first level takes guests to an expansive double living room, complete with two fireplaces.A wall of glass doors leads to an outdoor patio retreat.The regal dining room is designed for large-scale entertaining with a butler’s pantry, chef’s kitchen walk-in refrigeration room, and wine room attached.A stately library, ten-seat theatre with interactive seating and a planetarium also reside on the first floor.Rising to the second floor via elevator, guests can find sleeping quarters and the master suite with a sitting room, wet bar, powder room and master closets.The indulgent master bath is surrounded by honey onyx slabs, and an expansive terrace with an outdoor shower.An additional five bedrooms all with en-suite bathrooms are also on the second floor.Separate guest quarters with full apartment amenities including laundry, two bedrooms, private entrance and an eight bunkbed room are attached.In the homes expansive lower level, guests can relax in the private spa suite with a spa room with a fireplace complete with two hydraulic massage tables, jacuzzi, sauna, steam room, massage area, and showers.And those who need to stay fit can find squash, racquetball, basketball and volleyball courts with a fully-equipped training room and gym.A state-of-the-art entertainment lounge features a rock-climbing wall, skateboarding half-pipe, arts and crafts area, DJ booth and recording area, as well as a two-lane bowling alley.An enormous recreation pavilion features a yoga studio with fireplace, changing room, gym, covered porch, billiard area, steam room, massage room, and pilates room.Renowned Hamptons developer Joe Farrell expertly designed the mansion which has catered for several celebrity guests.He told property site The Real Deal last year: “If I had built to sell, I never would have put in so many of those things ... Things you’d never get your money back on, like closets that were hundreds of thousands of dollars.”In , Beyonce and husband Jay Z reportedly bought a mansion in The Hamptons for a cool m.The superstar couple, who are parents to daughter Blue and twins Sir and Rumi, are often seen on holiday in lavish and glamorous locations.Beyonce chilled out on the yacht with Blue Ivy on a recent trip to Italy

title: theresa may heads to face mps for the final time as her time in office comes to an end
story: The PM made a farewell statement in Downing Street, with loving husband Philip at her side - and slipped in a joke when interrupted by a protester shouting Stop Brexit, commenting: I think not.She was then driven to the Palace where she formally told the Queen she was resigning as the Prime Minister.Her leaving speech came an hour after she clashed with Mr Corbyn for the last time in fierce scenes which showed there was no love lost between the pair.Mrs Mays last session of Prime Ministers Questions was met with a standing ovation from MPs in a breach of Parliaments rules.Labour and the SNP refused to join the clapping and remained seated as she walked out of the chamber, visibly overcome with emotion.An hour later, Mrs May walked out of  Downing Street with Philip and said: I am about to go to Buckingham Palace to tender my resignation to Her Majesty the Queen and to advise her to ask Boris Johnson to form a new administration.I repeat my warm congratulations to Boris on winning the Conservative leadership election. I wish him and the Government he will lead every good fortune in the months and years ahead.Their successes will be our country’s successes, and I hope that they will be many.She repeated her call for the new PM to negotiate a Brexit deal in a possible warning to Mr Johnson that shed join the bid to block No Dealnecessary.Mrs May said: Much remains to be done – the immediate priority being to complete our exit from the European Union in a way that works for the whole United Kingdom.She concluded with a tribute to Philip, describing him as my greatest supporter and my closest companion.At that point a protester could be heard shouting Stop Brexit - prompting Mr May to quip That wasnt me while the outgoing PM said: I think not.She concluded: This is a country of aspiration and opportunity and I hope that every young girl who has seen a woman Prime Minister now knows for sure that there are no limits to what they can achieve.The couple then travelled to the Palace for their last audience with Her Majesty.They were greeted by Edward Young, the Queens private secretary, and Major Nana Kofi Twumasi-Ankrah, Her Majestys equerry, who shook hands with the Mays.They entered via the Kings Door of the Palace, where lady-in-waiting Lady Susan Hussey led them inside.A spokesman for Buckingham Palace said afterwards: The Right Honourable Theresa May MP had an Audience of The Queen this afternoon and tendered her resignation as Prime Minister and First Lord of the Treasury, which Her Majesty was graciously pleased to accept.Opening PMQs for the final time earlier today, Mrs May told the Commons: This afternoon I shall have an audience with Her Majesty the Queen.I will then continue with my duties in this house from the back benches, where I will continue to be the member of Parliament for Maidenhead.Askedshe was upset to be handing over to Boris, Mrs May hit back: I am pleased to hand over to an incoming leader of the Conservative party and Prime Minister who I worked with when he was in my Cabinet and who is committed to delivering on the vote of the British people in  and to delivering for the people of this country.She added: I look forward in the back benches to giving my full support to the next Prime Minister as he takes us forward to delivering on Brexit and continuing to deliver on those Conservative priorities.And she called on her success to make education funding his top priority after entering No.Jeremy Corbyn praised Mrs Mays sense of public duty and called on her to join him as a backbench rebel, blocking BoJos reckless Brexit plans alongside her Chancellor Philip Hammond.But he also launched a string of vicious attacks on her record, claiming she had driven an increase in poverty and crime and blasted: Does the Prime Minister have any regrets He also called on the incoming PM to call a snap election as soon as possible to let the people decide their future.Mrs May responded by paying tribute to her rival for his work in his local area - but also called on him to resign after losing the backing of his own MPs.She quipped: Can I finish by saying this - as a party leader who has accepted when her time is up, perhaps the time is now for him to do the same.It was an echo of David Camerons final PMQs, where he blasted: It might be in my party’s interest for him to sit there. It’s not in the national interest. I would say – for heaven’s sake, man, go!The attack was supported by ex-Labour MP Ian Austin, who said in the Commons: Its very clear to me that the vast majority of Labour MPs agree with her too.Mrs May also hit out at Mr Corbyn for blocking Brexit, saying: At every stage, his only object has been playing party politics and frankly he should be ashamed of himself.Her last Commons performance as PM was watched by husband Philip, who got a name check from Mrs May as she said she was very pleased hed come along to support him.Fierce critic Jacob Rees-Mogg attempted to build bridges with the outgoing leader, saying: As somebody who has not iniably seen eye-to-eye with the Prime Minister, may I thank her for her remarkable public service.And for showing that highest of virtues - a sense of duty - and on top of that being willing to deal with people who must on occasion be annoying to her with enormous courtesy.Mrs May finished the hour-long session - believed to be the longest PMQs ever - by saying: We are living through extraordinary political times, and this house is rightly at the centre of those events.Thats because of the vital link between every single member of this house and the communities we represent. Thats the bedrock of our parliamentary democracy and of our liberty.She concluded: That duty to serve my constituents will remain my greatest motivation.After Mrs May left the Commons the flood of resignations from her Government began.Chancellor Philip Hammond, Justice Secretary David Gauke, deputy PM David Lidington and International Development Secretary Rory Stewart all confirmed they wouldnt serve under Boris.Mr Hammond wrote to Mrs May saying: I believe that your successor must be free to choose a Chancellor who is fully aligned with his policy position.It has been a privilege to serve as your Chancellor for just over three years.Mr Lidington, the Cabinet Office Minister, added: After more than two decades of collective responsibility Im now relishing the prospect of speaking and campaigning freely for the things that matter to me and to my constituents.Mrs May has gone back to No for a final lunch with her staff.She will later visit Buckingham Palace to hand her resignation to the Queen, and will also make a short speech in Downing Street.Mr Johnson will formally take over as Prime Minister shortly afterwards.He is expected to make his own speech outside No, then will enter talks with security officials to ensure he is up to speed on the threats facing the UK.This evening the new PM is expected to announce the appointment of certain key Cabinet ministers.The full team will be unveiled tomorrow with the line-up of the top table providing a clue to how Boris will govern the country.Mrs May will speed away from London immediately and go to her Berkshire home with husband Philip.She has vowed to continue as backbench MP for Maidenhead under her successor Mr Johnson.Heres how Theresa Mays last day in office - and Boris Johnsons first - is playing out :pm May takes Prime Ministers Questions in the Commons for the final timepm She gives short farewell speech outside  Downing Street.pm May travels to Buckingham Palace and hands resignation to the Queen.pm Johnson goes to the Palace and kisses hands with Her Majesty, becoming the new Prime Ministerpm Boris arrives at No and gives his own speech before going inside for security briefingspm Johnson summons ministers who wont get a new job to his office and tells them theyre sackedpm The new PM starts appointing his Cabinet with at least six top jobs to be filled todayTomorrow the House of Commons starts its summer recess and will not sit again for five weeks.That means the new PM wont have to face a grilling from MPs until Wednesday, September .But Boris is weighing up whether to make a Commons statement tomorrow morning in a bid to stave off a rebellion from furious backbenchers.

title: pictures allied troops road berlin d day book
story: Harrowing pictures from the latter stages of World War Two include US soldiers running into battle as a shell bursts, a field full of abandoned German helmets, and a crash landing for an allied paratrooper.Another incredible image portrays the fearful yet stoic expression of a -year-old tank operator, captured just days before he was killed in action, and the gutted landscape of a Dutch town ravaged by constant air raids.Historian Brooke S. Blades’ new book The Americans from Normandy to the German Border: Rare Photographs from Wartime Archives offers an enthralling, chilling, and gruesome insight into what the American soldiers faced following the D-day landings in the summer ,  years ago.After tens of thousands of courageous allied soldiers tackled the terrying prospect of landing on France’s heavily fortied northern shore and managed to break through the Nazi’s defences, the Allied Forces were then tasked with beating the Third Reich troops back to Germany.Blades explains: “This book takes up the story of the massive American contribution to the campaign in north West Europe during the autumn and early winter of .“Following the dramatic breakout from the Normandy bridgehead, events moved fast with the liberation of Paris quickly following and the Allies closed in on the German border.“But the apparent collapse of the Nazis was illusory.As lines of communication ened and German resistance stfened, the Allied High Command was ided on the right strategy.The ill-fated Operation Market Garden brought home the reality that the war would continue into .The Siegried Line was penetrated and Aachen fell but the American First Army suffered heavy casualties in the Hurtgen Forest.As winter set in, the third Army crossed the Moselle River and into the Saar.“The stage was set for the costliest battle in American history – The Battle of The Bulge.”Following D-Day, the Allied Forces were locked in fierce, close encounter fighting in northern France in a six-week skirmish known at the ‘battle of the hedgerows’ due to the intimate fighting theatre.In particular larger communities such as Caen put up dramatic resistance and it took a huge amount of manpower and effort to sht the entrenched German defenders.More blood would be shed and a huge number of German prisoners of war interned following the formation of the ‘Falaise Pocket’ - a huge swath of Third Reich troops and their vehicles who ended up trapped due to a rapid pincer movement from the Allied Forces.Blades’ book also looks at other key events, including the liberation of Paris, Operation Dragoon, and the costly ‘Operation Market Garden’.Including approximately , involved on D-Day itself , during the Battle of Normandy over , Allied and German troops were killed, wounded or went missing overall.This figure includes around , Allied casualties, with nearly , killed amongst the ground forces and a further , deaths amongst the Allied air forces.German losses of around , were killed or wounded a further , were taken prisoner during the Campaign.Looking just at the fierce fighting which took place around the Falaise Pocketin August , the German Army suffered losses in excess of , men, including those taken prisoner.

story: Mrs May made her farewell speech with loyal husband Philip by her side, who she praised as her greatest supporter and closest companion.Theresa May gave an emotional speech outside of Number  at . pm on July , her husband Philip by her side.You can watch the former Prime Ministers farewell speech here.She told reporters: To serve as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom is the greatest honour.The heavy responsibilities are outweighed by the huge potential to serve your country.But you achieve nothing alone.And as I leave Downing Street, my final words are of sincere thanks.Earlier on she took questions in parliament for the last time, known as PMQS.In her final message to Jeremy Corbyn during her PMQs, Theresa May said: One thing we both have in common is a commitment to our constituencies, I saw that after the terrorist in Finsbury Park Mosque in his constituency.Perhaps I could just finish my exchange with him by saying this: As a party leader who has accepted when her time was up, perhaps the time is now for him to do the same Mays PMQs lasted  minutes, compared to David Camerons in  lasting just  minutes.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hottest day ever weather uk record temperature
story: The mercury is expected to soar to an unprecedented C, smashing the current record of .C set in Kent in August .The hot weather is blasting in from an African plume of Saharan air.Some forecast models show the high humidity levels could make the temperature feel like C on Thursday.Last night, the UKs hottest ever night-time temperature of .C in Brighton may have been broken.And today the Met Office said the temperature hit .C at Cavendish in Suffolk and reached .C in Writtle, Essex.At Heathrow in London, the mercury rose to .C, while at St Jamess Park it reached .C.The sweltering conditions prompted Network Rail to impose train speed restrictions in areas where tracks were at risk of buckling.Southeastern railway even urged commuters to avoid travelling, as services were expected to experience huge delays.Extreme weather action teamswere activated to keep passengers safe and trains running.Now emergency services warned the public to take precautions during the extreme heat.Temperatures reached .C on the Central Line this evening.Commuters were snapped appearing rather worse for wear, on packed tubes.Officials have also highlighted the risks of cooling off in the sea, lakes and rivers.The Rail Delivery Group, which represents the industry, advised passengers in London and the South East to consider changing their travel plans on Thursday because of the expected heat.Met Office Meteorologist Matthew Box said it is more likely both the .C July record and the all-time maximum of .C will fall before the end of the week.He said: “We now think there is an -per cent chance that the July record will be broken on Thursday with a -per cent chance the all-time record will fall.“Models indicate a lot of warm air coming up from the Continent especially across eastern parts of the country.“High pressure is over the Continent and this allowing energy from the sun to heat the region, this air is then going to come up and into the UK.“There is a chance that it will turn slightly fresher as we go into the weekend, however eastern Britain could remain very warm.”As temperatures soar across the country, emergency services warned the public to take precautions during the extreme heat and highlighted the risks of cooling off in the sea, lakes and rivers.And gritters could be brought out during the heatwave as temperatures could cause roads to melt.RAC Breakdown spokesman Rod Dennis said: “The sweltering heat is going to inevitably lead to some softer road surfaces over the next few days.“If you see some blacker patches of road or pavement, that’s the grip on roads that are starting melt.”The hottest day ever comes a year to the day after The Sun told how the planet was gripped by a mammoth killer heatwave, with temps hitting C in Britain.Experts at the Energy  Climate Intelligence Unit last night warned of the potential impact of todays forecast record temperature.Deputy director Peter Chalkley said: “Exactly a year to the day since The Sun’s iconic ‘world’s on fire’ frontpage, Britain could see its all-time temperature record broken.“In the past year the Met Office has told us that ’s heatwave was made around  times more likely by climate change.“Scientists have predicted and tracked the increased frequency and severity of heatwaves and the British public are increasingly concerned about climate change.“Experts are highlighting that older people and also the very young as well as farmers and even power stations can struggle in the increased heat we are seeing.”It comes after lightning storms triggered fires and rail disruption on Tuesday night.Incredible pictures captured the skies illuminated with arcs of lightning as powerful electrical storms.The Met Office last night issued a yellow warning for scattered thunderstorms covering the east of the country from Scotland down to London from pm on Thursday and into early Friday morning.It also warned flooding and lightning strikes could affect driving conditions, disrupt train services and lead to power cuts.Record-breaking temperatures are also expected across Europe.The most extreme heat will now build from central and northern France into ago.

title: deal boris follow may brexit door
story: He is only Prime Minister because of Theresa May’s failure to get Britain out of the EU on March .If Boris can’t get Brexit done, then he’ll be done.So what’s the plan  Well, it is to seek a deal while preparing for No Deal.Boris has long regarded a genuine threat to walk away without a deal as being a bit like the Trident nuclear deterrent: Because you have it, you don’t have to use it.But as one of those involved in devising this approach tells me, for it to work, “both elements of the strategy have to be credible”. In other words, both the No Deal preparation and the proposed deal must be realistic.This is where his key Brexit lieutenants Dominic Cummings and David Frost come in.They might be backroom appointments but they are as —not more — important to the success of Boris’s premiership as the Cabinet appointments he has made.Cummings is a unique figure in Westminster. He is interested in getting things done with little regard to what people think of him and the political niceties.It is thanks to Benedict Cumberbatch that Cummings has attracted something close to celebrity status in political circles. Cumberbatch played Cummings in the TV drama Brexit: The Uncivil War.He captured brilliantly Cummings’ drive and determination to win as the campaign chief for Vote Leave, and the fact he doesn’t care whose ego he ruffles in the process.In his new job, Cummings’ determination is already clear.Yesterday he was meant to be on the operating table under general anaesthetic.But once the offer came from Boris, he cancelled the operation. I am told he won’t have it done now until after October , Boris’s deadline for getting Brexit done.Cummings came in because the chance of getting the Vote Leave team back together to deliver Brexit after three years of drt simply had to be taken. The big challenge for this team is to get the UK ready for a No Deal Brexit.Cummings is well suited to his task. He knows how Whitehall works and how to succeed despite intense opposition he drove through Michael Gove’s Free Schools, which have proved hugely successful, against the objections of the educational establishment.Strikingly, in Boris’s new Government it is now Gove who is in charge of the No Deal planning.Getting the logistics and the necessary contingency plans sorted is one aspect of No Deal planning, and one that was shamefully neglected under Mrs May. But there also needs to be a political strategy for it.Many in the EU are convinced — thanks to the antics of Dominic Grieve, Philip Hammond and co — that Parliament will block No Deal.Or thatthe UK did leave without a deal on Halloween, it would come crawling back by Christmas.So they reckon there is no need to compromise as No Deal either won’t happen or will be only a temporary affair.The best way to deal with both the Parliamentary opposition to No Deal and the belief that the UK would come crawling back is for Boris to take a lead in the polls.If it was clear that a general election would lead to a majority for Boris, then Parliament would be less likely to throw obstacles in his way.That’s why Boris, in his Downing Street speech, tried to address the issues that cost the Tories their majority in : Social care, schools funding and police cuts.If the EU thought that Boris could do No Deal, and could politically sustain it, then it would have to decide whether it was prepared to compromise to avoid No Deal.The Irish Taoiseach, Leo Varadkar, would have to decide whether it is worth sticking with a backstop that is going to cause the very thing it was meant to avoid, a hard border on the island of Ireland.Varadkar would also have to consider whether he really wants to go through with No Deal when it would do more damage to the Irish economy than the UK’s. This is where David Frost comes in.No, not the late, great TV personality but the former Foreign Office diplomat who is going to be Boris’s point man for negotiations with the EU.Frost knows his way round the chancelleries of Europe, he is a former Foreign Office Europe Director and he also knows what Boris wants on Brexit.He was his special adviser when Boris was Foreign Secretary and was there when Boris decided to quit over Mrs May’s Chequers plan.His role is to craft a Brexit agreement that delivers what Boris thinks the UK needs AND one that has a chance of being accepted by the EUthe alternative is No Deal. This isn’t going to be easy, and it isn’t going to be done quickly.Those involved admit thatthe EU is going to blink, it will not be until the October EU Council at the earliest, which is just two weeks away from the October  deadline. As one of those working in the new No puts it: “Fasten your seatbelts, it’s going to be a bumpy ride.”But after years in which the EU thought they had the measure of the British Prime Minister, we now have a team who might just have what it takes to pull Brexit back from the brink. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: one eyed lion looks like scar
story: The Lion King films character is named after his own eye wound.And this poor fella called Benna was injured in a territorial fight with another male at a Kenya reserve.Amateur photographer Fabrizio Bignotti spotted this one-eyed lion at Maasai Mara National Reserve in Kenya.Though he is permanently scarred, he appeared to be in a good mood as he guarded his pride.Mr Bignotti, , from Noa, near Milan, Italy, said: “He is a crazy-looking lion, but he is very sweet.“He lost one eye because of a brutal fight.Disney’s remake of the  film debuted at cinemas on Friday and dominated the box office by collecting around £ million globally over the weekend.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: university degrees slam doors shut
story: A decent set of A-level results and the kids can get themselves into a university. There, they can enrol in a course on gender studies and emerge in three years with a degree which will not help them one bit to get a decent job.And as a consequence they will be at least £, in debt. But they’ll have a piece of paper which will tell possible employers: “Look — I’ve been a total mug for three years. Gizza job!”The unemployment rate for students at Britain’s worst universities, such as East London and London South Bank, is around about double the national rate for young people.In other words, going to university worsened their chances of getting a job.That’s not what they were led to believe, is it. They were told a university degree would open doors for them. Not slam the doors shut in their spotty faces. And leave them with a whopping loan to pay off.Our young people have been conned for far too long.We have a new Prime Minister now. And I think it would be a good ideahe took a very close look at higher education. OK, he’s got Brexit to sort out first, fine. But by November , this should be his priority.We are misleading our young people. Far too many -year-olds go to university and end up mired in debt, with rotten degrees in stupid subjects. While all students have to scrimp and save to get through their three years.Here’s what I would doI were Education Secretary.End all tuition fees right now. Make university education absolutely free, and make sure those who go get decent living grants.How do we pay for that  Easy. Cut the number of people going to university by  per cent. Not everyone is academically minded. University should be only for those who are.Back when I went to uni only ten per cent of my peer group got in.But for the rest there were apprenticeships. Learning in the workplace. And those sorts of options should be considered not inferior to university, but absolutely equal. And the benefits stressed to the kids.Three years after leaving school a university kid will be earning nothing. If you’ve been on an apprenticeship for three years you’ll be earning a decent whack.We have over-stressed the importance and attraction of a college education to our young people, given them unrealistic expectations and made them pay through the nose for it. And at the same time we’ve devalued education by doing this.So there’s the challenge, Boris. Get on to the private sector and get some more apprenticeships up and running.And close down the awful former polytechnics charging a king’s ransom for a crap degree.ONE of the best things about BoJo becoming Prime Minister is that the perpetually screeching Yasmin Alibhai-Brown has vowed to leave the country.Brown loathes the white English working class.So it was always a mystery to me why she stayed in the country. Seeing as there are quite a lot of white, English, working-class people.Anyway, she vowed to get the hell outJohnson became PM.Trouble is, people say stuff like this but rarely act on it.I suggest we set up a crowdfunding page for her plane ticket and maybe throw in some extra money for en-route snacks and stuff.Off you go to Heathrow, Yazza.I MADE a list a few weeks ago about the  things I most dislike in the world.At No was Andrew Lloyd Webber musicals.At No was Taylor Swt.And No was cats .So take a guess as to what new film I’m not going to be watching any time soon It’s my nightmare, all wrapped up in two hours.CARL BEECH made a series of outrageous claims of sexual abuse, torture and murder by members of the old Conservative establishment.This serial liar and fantasist will soon be sentenced for his crimes.The reason the police believed this madman is because they have been told they must. They are no longer allowed to employ common sense.In order to be politically correct they have had to shed all semblance of judgment.THE job of a bookshop, you would have thought, is to sell books.Trouble is, they are useless at it. They are politically biased and cater solely to a tiny minority of gibbering liberals.I’ve got a book out at the moment, called The Great Betrayal – The True Story Of Brexit. I’ve had complaints from people who want to read it that they can’t find it in bookshops.The bookshop staff say they thought there wouldn’t be any interest in it. But it was the No best-seller in the country and was No on Amazon worldwide. It’s pure political bias.If you want the book – go on Amazon.TOP prize in the “Most Rational and Measured Response to Boris Johnson Becoming Prime Minister” goes to – of course – .For this headline: “The Clown Is Crowned As The Country Burns In Hell.”Followed by , words of hysterical drivel.Brilliant. The Left really don’t like it when they don’t get their own way.Anyway, this is but the first example of BDS – Boris Derangement Syndrome. Don’t worry. Lots more of it to come.MAGIC grandpa has a cunning plan!The Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn announced to the Press that he was going to “surprise Boris Johnson” by calling a vote of no confidence.Here’s a tip, you Jew-bothering, bearded c**kwomble.If you want something to be a surprise for someone, don’t tell every newspaper in the country.THE Islamist crackpots in Iran have hijacked two of our oil tankers. Causing a pretty grave crisis.But why isn’t the Royal Navy escorting British ships through the Strait of Hormuz, when we know the danger  Andthey’re not ready yet to do that, why did we impound an Iranian tanker three weeks ago, knowing there would be reprisals We have been naive and underprepared. I’m not sure anyone has noticed yet.Anyway, she immediately demonstrated her full-blooded support for democracy.She said evenpeople voted leave in a second referendum, she’d still ignore it.Swimsuit only likes democracy when people vote the way she wants. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: work ban hot temperatures labour
story: Leader Jeremy Corbyn has vowed to put an end to sweaty workplaces.Employers will have to introduce air conditioning, extra breaks and let staff turn up in shorts and T shirts under the plan.And workers doing physically tough jobs will get to down tools over C .Shadow business minister Laura Pidcock said: “As we’re all being reminded this week, working in hot conditions is really uncomfortable, often stressful and it makes us less productive and even ill.“Plus it’s often the lowest paid and most insecure workers who suffer the most.Labour said global warming means sweltering heatwaves are here to stay.But their proposals risk fuelling the problem by forcing employers to install energy-guzzling air conditioning units – which is adding to climate change.The free-market think-tank, the Institute of Economic Affairs, said Labour is just chasing headlines and that employers already have to provide a ‘reasonable’ temperature.The IEA’s Andy Mayer said: “Labour’s proposal, while eye-catching, would make no one better off, but instead reduce the flexibility of employers to manage those risks.“What is appropriate for the socialist book store in Islington is not appropriate for a foundry in Sheffield or kiln in Stoke.“Micro-legislating in this way will simply add to their costs and risk unemployment.”Britain has been baking in a heatwave this week, with temperatures set to soar to C  today.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: spacex starhopper launch aborted rocket bursts into flames
story: The rocket was supposed to take off and hover  metres above the ground as part of a test in Boca Chica Beach, Texas, US, on Wednesday.But the test was called off when the Raptor engine burned for several second before shutting down and engulfing the spaceship in flames.The Starhopper is a smaller scale version of the Starship rocket that Elon Musks wants to send to the moon as early .SpaceX previously announced plans to send a group of artists around the moon on Starship in .The blaze was soon extinguished and the Starhopper appeared to suffer minimal damage.During SpaceXs live stream of the launch, an official commentator said: It appears as though we have had an abort on todays test as you can see there the vehicle did not lt off today.But as I mentioned before this is a development programme, today was a test flight designed to test the boundaries of the vehicle.It comes one week after the Starhopper went up in flames during a static fire test.The Starhopper is used to test the craft in live-fire environments and perform short flights.SpaceX boss Elon Musk confirmed that fire had been caused by a post test fuel leak but added there had been no major damage.It is thought that the water jet may have caused the small fire to ignite the vapour, causing the fireball, according to Tech Crunch.It has been hoped that the first commercial mission for SpaceX’s Starship would launch in , but it is not knownthe latest incident has caused those plans to be delayed.SpaceX suffered a setback to its plans when it lost control of three satellites it had launched into Earth’s orbit just a few weeks before.The Starlink probes were meant to form part of a huge network of satellites that will eventually beam high-speed internet to people on Earth.In total,  satellites were successfully deployed into Earths orbit on May  after a short flight aboard a SpaceX rocket.But it was then admitted mission control had lost contact with some of them.SpaceX boss Elon Musk has previously said he plans to send up nearly , satellites by the mid-s.The company though had better success with the launch of the first ever solar powered “sailing” spacecraft.It is hoped the vehicle could solve the issue of fuel storage in space which could expand the possibilities of further deep space travel.

title: incredible shed bar competition prize
story: The competition, celebrating the best of British sheds, has whittled down just  hopefuls to the final.Now in its th year, the lucky winner of the shed competition will be decided by public vote.The constructions will compete in seven hotly-contested categories including budget structure and unexpected shed for the  title and a £, cash prize.A giant crown, a winners plaque and £ worth of garden woodwork products are also up for grabs.Among those reaching the final is a recreation of an artist’s workshop in Bristol, complete with paintings and easels.Another is a shed converted into a beach bar shack based in Northamptonshire, with its very own Enter the Freaky Tiki sign.Also vying for the winner’s crown is a Shakespeare themed boat-come-shed, inspired by the play The Tempest.Other finalists include a two-floor playhouse that required planning permission, and a space station shed equipt with a plethora of tools.This year a new category has been added to showcase the best of Natures Haven, embracing the trend for the outdoors and garden maintenance.A public vote will decide the best shed in each category before a “ of shed experts” decides the overall winner of the Cuprinol-sponsored competition.Categories for Shed of the Year include unexpected, cabin or summerhouse, workshop and studio, pub and entertainment, budget and unique.Playrooms for children have been popular additions to this year’s entries, with owners keen to find a place for their kids to get away from technology and be at one with their imagination.This year, the  saw the Attenborough effect emerge in the designs, with many of the entries showing a steer towards sustainability, using reclaimed and recycled materials for their work of art.Head judge and founder of the competition, Andrew Wilcox, said: “We’ve been absolutely blown away by the incredible, imaginative and innovative sheds entered into this year’s competition.Every year there are more and more outstanding entries that take us by surprise.“The creativity and imagination of all entrants never fail to amaze the judges. This year’s bunch are second to none.“We’ve been really impressed by the aesthetics of the sheds - especially those that entered the brand new Nature’s Haven category with entrants really demonstrating how important it is to welcome nature into our lives and our gardens.”Last year’s Shed of the Year winner, George Smallwood, from Sheffield, harnessed self-watering technology in his Bee Eco Shed, which allowed vegetable and herb gardens to grow and insects and bees to thrive.Paying tribute to the Bee Eco Shed, Andrew Wilcox praised the “practical, yet brilliant design that made you closer to nature.”

title: aboard double decker lies checker
story: NewsAll aboard our double decker lies checker: Mirror Bus takes Boris to taskThe Mirror double-decker, backed by union the GMB, set off in London yesterday as we vowed to hold him to account for every untruth utteredShareCommentsByPaul RoutledgeAndy LinesLiz Dunphy:,  JUL NewsThe Mirrors Boris Bus as it travels through central London "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPlenty of you reckon lying chancer Boris Johnson would throw the nation under the bus to advance his own interests.And he pretty much proved this with his Vote Leave battle bus and its whopper about £million a week for the NHS after Brexit .So we decided to get a special service on the road – dedicated to following his journey as Prime Minister and keeping an eye on every twist and turn of his route. The Mirror double-decker, backed by union the GMB, set off in London yesterday as we vowed to hold him to account for every untruth uttered, launching hashtags #BorisLieBuster and #WeAreWatchingYouBoris. And the reaction made us wonder how long it will be before his time in the UK’s driving seat is over. The open-topper had dozens of passengers and crowds cheered it around Parliament Square and Westminster.    Boris lookalike Drew Galdron sang songs including I’m the King of the Bungle – and Fleetwood Mac’s Little Lies boomed out over the speakers. But behind the fun, the message was deadly serious. GMB members waving placards bearing some of his porkies urged Boris to drop his hardline Brexit stance – and stop lying now he has won the highest office. Chief Tim Roache warned: “We’re watching you, Boris. No-deal Brexit will bring ­political Armageddon. Boris offers no hope to workers.” Harry Picken, , of Barnes, South West London, has just graduated from Lancaster University in history and politics. He said: “Boris represents everything wrong about society. “He is not someone [to] be trusted. He was part of a campaign that lied. He doesn’t intend to unite the country.”    Christine Golding, education convenor for the GMB and chair of the National School Committee, said: “When I found out Boris was going to be Prime Minister, I was angry. “His record doesn’t come across as someone listening to us. I want to know what he’s going to do for education. I work with people who have two jobs and still can’t afford to live. How is he going to help  We’ve been decimated in schools. Is he going to put money back in  Of course he’s not.” And teacher Sophie Ingram, , from Suffolk, said: “I’m scared for the future. I have to teach ‘British values’ of tolerance and respect and Boris is not the poster boy for that.  The children I teach are scared too. Tory austerity has meant some teachers feed pupils and even their parents.” Our passengers made it clear that as we buckle up for a bumpy ride with Boris, we must hold him to account. The Mirror will not let him use lies to steer us down the wrong road. Paul Routledgeaposs view The top deck of the Mirror Boris Lie Buster bus was the coolest place in London. We caught the breeze while our Boris lookalike was shooting it. Tourists gawped, motorists hooted their horns in support and sightseers even thought he was the real thing. Three years ago the Johnson bus lied to take us out of the EU. Yesterday the Mirror Liebuster bus told the truth. Our Boris exposed the porkies in songs like I’m The King Of The Bungle and It had To Be Eu-Who-Who… On College Green by Westminster we even got a wave from hardline Tory Brexiteer Nigel Evans MP. Army veterans obviously thought our PM was the real deal because they shouted: “Don’t forget your promises.”

title: alastair campbell i know what
story: NewsopinionAlastair Campbell: I know what it takes to be PM and it wont end well for BorisBoris is lazy. That doesn’t mean he can’t put in the hours. But they are devoted to the game of politics and media, not the hard graft of policy and delivery.ShareCommentsByAlastair Campbell:,  JUL NewsopinionBoris Johnson and Alastair Campbell "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhat a turnaround for David Cameron. As his career burnt in the ashes of a party ­management tactic – the EU ­referendum – he was destined to go down as the worst Prime ­Minister of modern times. Three years later, he is only the third worst. He lost the referendum. Theresa May failed to deliver on the result. Despite her “legacy tour” and though there is some “poisoned chalice” sympathy, she ­nonetheless left office having failed in virtually everything she set out to do. The burning injustices still burn. Brexit has not been ­delivered.  Now Boris Johnson takes over. I see no way that can end well for him or, more importantly, for Britain. I predict he will be even worse than his predecessors.    Those of us on the losing side of political arguments right now must be humble enough to admit we could be wrong, and that he may prove us all wrong. But I have known Johnson for a long time. First, as fellow ­journalists. Then, with him covering the government I worked for. Then, with both of us on the political front line. Now, with me as a commentator cum anti-Brexit campaigner and him as Prime Minister. It is hard to compute.  Because I can think of no other senior position being filled by someone so unqualied to do the job, especially at this crucial time for the country. Older readers may remember when a businessman called Michael Knighton took over Manchester United. When I think of Johnson, I think of Knighton ball-juggling at Old Trafford. I am currently – thank God, given what is happening back home – in Australia.    And the general impression I get from Aussies is that they think, what with Brexit and now Johnson, the Mother Country has gone bonkers.   In his head, Johnson is Winston Churchill. In truth, he is a pound-shop Trump. He lies with the same ease as the US President. Like Trump, he seeks credit for anything good. Think London Olympics, in which he played a minor role but used it to promote himself, as he does with everything he touches. Like Trump, he shts blame when it should be his. Think the failed vanity projects, like his island airport or his garden bridge. And also, think of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe languishing in Iranian jails and psychiatric units while the man, who made it so much worse for her, enters Downing Street to take charge of UK foreign policy.  He is lazy. That doesn’t mean he can’t put in the hours. But they are devoted to the game of politics and media, not the hard graft of policy and delivery. He is dismissive of detail. He is loose with his language as well as his morals. He is a bad judge of character. He is untrustworthy. He has no moral compass or fixed beliefs – hence writing two articles, one for Remain, one for Leave, before deciding that his own interests in the referendum were best served by backing Leave. Everything he has e ver done in his le has been largely about himself, his profile, his career. And that same narcissism is reflected in his personal le where, as his famous shouting match with his current girlfriend Carrie Symonds appeared to show, it all has to be on his terms and to hell with the consequences for others.  Fair play to him on one level – everything he set out to do he has done it. Got all the positions he sought at Eton and Oxford. Made a name for himself as a journalist not least in Brussels by making up stories and, to the Daily ’s shame, getting away with it. Edited a magazine. Won a seat in Parliament. Won two terms as Mayor of London, historically a Labour city. Made history in leading the winning side in the referendum. Became Foreign Secretary. And now, the job he always saw as his destiny, sitting in Churchill’s chair.  But now he is there, his mettle will be tested as never before. He will have a large number of right-wing press sycophants who will help cover up his failings and exaggerate his successes.

He will hope his new team can form a guard around him as he prepares us for the potentially catastrophic move.Among those on the rise was Home Secretary Sajid Javid , who is now Chancellor.  Former Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab became Foreign Secretary and Priti Patel made a remarkableto the frontbench as Home Secretary. The most high-profile casualty was leadership rival and Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt , who quit after refusing another job, thought to be Defence Secretary. Another shock victim was Defence Secretary Penny Mordaunt, who had backed Mr Hunt.The hour-long purge was carried out in the Commons to spare victims the humiliation of walking out in front of photographers and TV cameras. It was unclear who was sacked and who chose to jump before being pushed. But other victims included International Trade Secretary Liam Fox – another supporter of Mr Hunt. The Cabinet ministers axed will get more than £, between them in taxpayer-funded severance payments. Meanwhile, Larry the Downing Street cat clung on and is still Chief Mouser to the Cabinet Office. The moggie, seen in Downing Street yesterday as Mr Johnson moved in, has held the position since , when David Cameron appointed him from Battersea Dogs and Cats Home. OUT   FOREIGN SECRETARY Jeremy Hunt, , Remain, backed himselfThe leadership hopeful now finds himself on the backbenches for the first time while the Tories are in Government.His crushing defeat to Boris Johnson in the No race gave the new PM the power to demote him from the Foreign Office – power he ruthlessly executed last night. DEFENCE SECRETARY Penny Mordaunt, , Leave, backed HuntDays before she was sacked, she used a weekend magazine interview to speak of the job she loved. “I hope I have longer than a few weeks,” said Mordaunt, who only landed her dream post in April. “Boris knows me, he’ll know who I am, he’ll know my personality type, he knows I’m a team player.” It seems not.COMMUNITIES SECRETARY James Brokenshire, , Remain, backed JohnsonDespite backing Johnson, the Communities Secretary was unceremoniously sacked by the new PM. Brokenshire, who resigned as Northern Ireland Secretary to beat lung cancer in , ed to government when his party needed him most , yet this was his reward.INTERNATIONAL TRADE SECRETARY Liam Fox, , Leave, backed HuntA lelong Eurosceptic, he surprised many when he snubbed Johnson and threw his weight behind Hunt’s No bid. That probably sealed his fate. TRANSPORT SECRETARY Chris Grayling, , Leave, backed JohnsonMany Tories will be glad to see the back of “Failing” Grayling. Critics point to his long record of bungles, many of which have been reversed as he has been dumped on another ministry.NORTHERN IRELAND Karen Bradley, , Remain, unclearServed as Culture Secretary before being promoted to the Northern Ireland brief.BUSINESS SECRETARY Greg Clark, , Remain, backed HuntClark spent his final days in office warning of the consequences of crashing out without a deal.SCOTTISH SECRETARY David Mundell, , Remain, backed HuntSacked despite desperately trying to U-turn on his previous comments about the new PM. IN   CHANCELLOR Sajid Javid, , Remain, backed JohnsonAs Home Secretary, he was already the first person of Muslim heritage to hold one of the four Great Offices of State. The multimillionaire former banker is the son of Pakistani immigrants.HOME SECRETARYPriti Patel, , Leave, backed JohnsonThe former International Development Secretary ed to government after being sacked by Theresa May in . She is a hard-right Tory who backs tax cuts, opposed gay marriage and supported the death penalty until .FOREIGN SECRETARYDominic Raab, , Leave, backed JohnsonThe hard Brexit-backing right-winger famously only learned how important the Dover-Calais trade route was after becoming Brexit Secretary. In  he said “feminists are now amongst the most obnoxious bigots” and it was time for men to start “burning their briefs”. In , he said most foodbank users were not “languishing in poverty” and just had “cash flow” problems.DEFENCE SECRETARY Ben Wallace, , Remain, backed JohnsonPromoted from Security Minister, where he dealt with intelligence outlining the threats to the UK, Wallace has a rich background in the military. Yet despite being a Sandhurst-trained platoon commander in the Scots Guards, he was not first choice for Defence Secretary – the new PM offered the job to his defeated rival, Jeremy Hunt, first.CHIEF WHIP Mark Spencer, , Remain, backed JohnsonThe MP for Sherwood since  will be the PM’s own Sherf of Nottingham, trying to win over Tory MPs in Brexit votes despite a working majority of just two.HEALTH SECRETARY Matt Hancock, , Remain, backed JohnsonHancock may have expected a promotion but he remains as Health Secretary – a job which gave him a prominent role in May’s cabinet. The tech-obsessed MP pulled out of the leadership race after he came sixth in the first round of MPs’ votes. INTERNATIONAL TRADE Liz Truss, , Remain, backed JohnsonShe coveted the Treasury job but scooped a promotion after campaigning passionately for Johnson.CHANCELLOR OF THE DUCHY OF LANCASTER Michael Gove, , Leave, unclear who he backedThe comeback kid who scuppered Boris’s  leadership bid has been given a role at the new PM’s side.BUSINESS Andrea Leadsom, , Leave, backed JohnsonThe former leader of the Commons is a right-winger who said she would be a better PM than Mrs May.EDUCATION Gavin Williamson, , Remain, backed JohnsonDisgraced former Defence Secretary was axed over the Huawei leaks row.

story: NewsCabinet reshuffle in full: All the MPs backed, sacked and cracked in Boris Johnson’s teamBoris Johnson is assembling Britains most right-wing government since the s after more than half the Cabinet resigned or got sacked.
