More than half of Theresa Mayaposs cabinet -  out of  - were either sacked or resigned in the new PMaposs brutal reshuffle. Both Remainers and supporters of leadership rival Jeremy Hunt were shown the door as Johnson ruthlessly dumped enemies - including Mr Hunt himself who quit after refusing a demotion to Defence Secretary. Right-wing Tories Sajid Javid, Priti Patel and Dominic Raab were ushered in as Chancellor, Home Secretary and Foreign Secretary respectively. Health Secretary Matt Hancock and DWP chief Amber Rudd kept their jobs after swallowing their pride - and principles - to offer some support for Mr Johnson. And disgraced former Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson ed as Education Secretary despite having to resign over a national security leak .    Itaposs thought to be the biggest clearout of Government ministers in political history - one that takes us back to the ideology of Margaret Thatcher and rewards hard Leavers as Mr Johnson tilts towards a No Deal Brexit. It shocked Westminster with its speed and viciousness, rewarding loyalists and ejecting ministers who were key to Mrs May’s regime, and those he feared might torpedo his plan to tear Britain out of the EU without a deal on October . Itaposs also so big that the sacked ministers are in line for more than £, in severance pay between them. So whoaposs backed for promotion, whoaposs sacked by the boss, and whoaposs cracked under the pressure in Boris Johnsonaposs new-look team  Weaposve had a look at them all - and their more chequered records. This piece is being updated throughout the Cabinet reshuffle. BACKED: The new Cabinet in full  Prime Minister: Boris Johnson Chancellor: Sajid Javid Home Secretary: Priti Patel Foreign Secretary: Dominic Raab Defence Secretary: Ben Wallace Cabinet Office Minister: Michael Gove Trade Secretary: Liz Truss Chief Secretary to the Treasury: Rishi Sunak Health Secretary: Matt Hancock Work and Pensions Secretary: Amber Rudd Environment Secretary: Theresa Villiers Brexit Secretary: Stephen Barclay Education Secretary: Gavin Williamson Culture Secretary: Nicky Morgan Business Secretary: Andrea Leadsom Communities Secretary: Robert Jenrick Justice Secretary: Robert Buckland Scottish Secretary: Alister Jack Transport Secretary: Grant Shapps Northern Ireland Secretary: Julian Smith Wales Secretary: Alun Cairns Conservative Party Chairman and Minister without Portfolio: James Cleverly Leader of the House of Commons: Jacob Rees-Mogg Leader of the House of Lords: Baroness Evans Universities Minister: Jo Johnson Housing Minister: Esther McVey Immigration Minister: Brandon Lewis Paymaster General: Oliver Dowden   SACKED  CRACKED: All  Tories sacked or resigned  Theresa MayDavid LidingtonPhilip HammondJeremy HuntPenny MordauntDavid GaukeGreg ClarkLiam FoxDamian HindsJames BrokenshireChris GraylingDavid MundellKaren BradleyRory StewartJeremy WrightMel StrideJulian SmithPORTRAITS OF THE INS AND OUTS BACKED: New hires to Cabinet Chief Whip: Mark Spencer VOTED REMAIN  The MP for Sherwood since  will be the PMaposs own Sherf of Nottingham, trying to win over Tory MPs in Brexit votes despite a working majority of just one or two. Itaposs an about-turn for Mr Spencer - who voted Remain in the  referendum. The state-educated politician studied at Shuttleworth Agricultural College in Bedfordshire and joined his familyaposs farming and farm shop business. He joined Parliament in  where he was a backbencher for six years. His big break was in the Tory whipsapos office, which he joined in June . He prompted fury in  by suggesting a dying benefit claimant, sanctioned after he turned up four minutes late, should learn the discipline of timekeeping. Labour MP Lisa Nandy said the man hadn’t eaten for  days and looked like he was dying but Mr Sherwood cut in: It is important that those who are seeking employment learn the discipline of timekeeping. Separately, Mr Spencer - who receives at least £, in rent per year from a farm - was one of  Tory landlords who voted against a Commons bid to force all homes to be fit for human habitation in .    Home Secretary: Priti Patel VOTED LEAVE  Shamed Tory ex minister Priti Patel will be handed a plum job in Boris Johnsonaposs top team - with some tipping her as a possible Home Secretary. Theresa May sacked Ms Patel as International Development Secretary in  after she had aposoff-the-booksapos meetings with senior Israeli officials during a aposfamily holidayapos. But Mr Johnson was expected to trumpet herto the Cabinet as part of a record number of ethnic minority politicians in the team. The -year-old MP for Witham, Essex, is a hard-right Tory who backs tax cuts and supported the death penalty until . Sheaposs also a Brexiteer aposultraapos who voted against Theresa Mayaposs deal all three times in Parliament. She was slammed in December for suggesting the government could use possible Brexit food shortages as leverage. A government report said No Deal could prompt food shortages in Ireland - infamously crippled by the th Century potato famine. But Ms Patel told The Times: Why hasnapost this point been pressed home during negotiations  The grammar school-educated Tory apparatchik was born in London to Gujarati parents who fled Uganda in the s and studied at Essex and Keele Universities. She worked for the Tories and Sir James Goldsmithaposs Referendum Party in the s before ing as William Hagueaposs deputy press secretary from  to  - eventually becoming an MP in . Civil liberties campaigners will be concerned about Ms Patelaposs appointment as Home Secretary. For many years she argued for theof capital punishment - though she says her mind has changed on the subject in recent years.    Foreign Secretary: Dominic Raab VOTED LEAVE  Dominic Raab is a hard Brexit backing, tax slashing right-wing ideologue who famously only learned how important the Dover-Calais trade route was for Britain after becoming Brexit Secretary. After crashing out of the race to succeed Theresa May, Mr Raab backed Boris Johnson and has been rewarded for his loyalty with one of the great offices of state. An ex-Foreign Office lawyer,  he left the civil service to become chief of staff to another former Brexit Secretary David Davis. He was elected MP for Esher and Walton in  and joined the government in , quickly rising through the ranks. Mr Raab in his short spell as Brexit Secretary admitted that he hadnapost fully read the Good Friday Agreement. In  Mr Raab said feminists are now amongst the most obnoxious bigots and said it was time for men to start burning their briefs. In  he said most food bank users were not languishing in poverty but were instead had cash flow problems and has branded Brits the worst idlers in the world. He will also be First Minister of State, which effectively makes him Deputy Prime Minister. Education Secretary: Gavin Williamson VOTED REMAIN Gavin Williamson was sacked as Defence Secretary over leaks from the National Security Council. That was  days ago. Heaposs now ing to frontline politics as Secretary of State for Education. Itaposs unclear whether this also signals ato government for Cronus the tarantula. Business Secretary: Andrea Leadsom VOTED LEAVE Andrea Leadsom resigned from Theresa Mayaposs cabinet a little over two months ago in protest against her Brexit Strategy. She stood in the election to replace Mrs May, but was eliminated in the first round of voting. She placed eighth out of  candidates, attracting just  votes from her fellow Tory MPs. Culture Secretary:Secretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs: Theresa Villiers VOTED LEAVE Theresa Villiers will replace Michael Gove as Environment Secretary.It marks ato Cabinet for the former Northern Ireland Secretary, who served for four years from .Villiers was one of the six Cabinet ministers who came out in support of Brexit during the EU referendum. Following the referendum, on  July , Villiers resigned from her position as Northern Ireland Secretary after saying that Theresa May had offered her a post outside the Cabinet which was not one which I felt I could take on. But despite solid Brexit credentials in the eyes of Team Boris, Villiers may not survive the next election, she has a majority of just  votes in her seat of Chipping Barnet. Culture Secretary: Nicky Morgan VOTED REMAIN The former Education Secretary was once part of the Tories’ pro-EU wing that proved awkward for May. But her acceptance of the result, and her support for Johnson during the leadership contest, meant ato Cabinet was likely. MP for the marginal seat of Loughborough, she impressed at Education after being drafted in to repair the damage to relations with teachers inflicted by Michael Gove. At Culture, her job will be to revive the ministry which some believe has suffered under the lacklustre leadership of Jeremy Wright. The job is known in Westminster as “Minister for Fun” because perks include free tickets to major sporting events, film and music award ceremonies, and nights at the opera or pop concerts. Morgan will certainly bring more spark to the role than Wright, but she will have had to convince Johnson she will fully back his fallback plan for a no-deal Brexit. International Development Secretary: Alok Sharma VOTED REMAIN  The MP for Reading West was expected to reach the Cabinet table for the first time after spending three years as a junior minister. The married dad-of-two, , attended the private Reading Blue Coat school and the University of Salford before qualying as a Deloitte chartered accountant. He spent  years in banking including investment banking before joining Parliament in . He was made a Foreign Office minister in  followed by the Communities Department and Department for Work and Pensions. Last year he faced shouts of apospathetic!apos as he tried to deny Universal Credit was forcing people to food banks - something his boss Amber Rudd later admitted. He also admitted the DWP dropped the ball when a scathing internal report on the benefit was published almost  months late. He voted Remain in the  EU referendum. Transport Secretary: Grant Shapps VOTED LEAVE BUT HAS SINCE CHANGED HIS MIND An unexpectedto the Cabinet for Grant Shapps, who has been out of the top team since . He was demoted by David Cameron from his job as party co-chairman and Minister without Portfolio after revelations about his second job and use of the assumed names Michael Green and Sebastian Fox. His demotion came after he admitted to having over-firmly denied having had a second job while he was an MP. Scotland Secretary: Alister Jack VOTED LEAVE Alister Jackaposs appointment was met with a resounding who in the corridors of Westminster. And with good reason. Heaposs only been an MP since .In just two years, heaposs managed to have had a role on the Treasury Select Committee, be appointed an aide to Andrea Leadsom and be made an Assistant Government Whip. And now heaposs in the Cabinet. Chief Secretary to the Treasury: Rishi Sunak VOTED LEAVE Local Government Minister Mr Sunak is considered a rising star of the Conservative Party.He is seen as a capable media performer and a confident politician with detail.An early backer of Boris Johnson, Mr Sunak was wheeled out by his campaign to defuse accusations that their candidate was a racist. In the Brexit referendum, Mr Sunak backed leaving the European Union.A former entrepreneur he worked in Calornia as an investor before in  winning the ultra-safe Conservative seat of Richmond in Yorkshire, after former leader William Hague stood down. Mr Sunak is married to Akshata Murthy, daughter of Indian businessman and billionaire N. R. Narayana Murthy. Housing minister: Esther McVey VOTED LEAVE Itaposs a demotion from her previous job as Work and Pensions Secretary, but welfare slasher Esther McVey has been brought back into the cabinet as a Housing Minister. Universities Minister: Jo Johnson VOTED REMAIN Boris Johnson has given his brother Jo his old job back. Johnson Jr was minister for Universities and Science from , until Theresa May moved him to transport in . He quit as a minister in November so he could back a second Brexit referendum. It will be interesting to see what he doesit looks like weaposre heading for no-deal. Paymaster General: Oliver Dowden VOTED REMAIN A paid-up member of the political establishment, Mr Dowden rose through the ranks of Conservative wonkery before ending up in No as an adviser to David Cameron, and promoted to deputy chief of staff. He once joked to an American interviewer that his job as a special advisor was day-to-day crisis management and he is seen by Tory insiders as a safe pair of hands.In  Mr Dowden, who is called aposOliveapos by friends, was elected to the safe tory seat of Hertsmere in Hertfordshire in .He was also given a goodbye gong by departing PM and former Boss David Cameron becoming a  Commander of the Order of the British Empire.Mr Dowden backed Remain in the  referendum but has not joined the group of awkward Tory MPs opposing Brexit.But as a close ally of the Cameron project, his promotion will be a potential red flag to the Tory traditionalists and eurosceptic hardliners who have pushed Mr Johnson to power. BACKED: Promoted from within Chancellor of the Exchequer: Sajid Javid VOTED REMAIN A reluctant remainer in the referendum, Sajid Javid is a born-again Brexiteer and has been promoted to the second-highest job in government. Mr Javid ran for the leadership himself before swinging behind Mr Johnson in his race to be Prime Minister. Multi-millionaire banker Sajid Javid was the first Home Secretary from an ethnic minority. The son of a bus driver, he was elected MP for Bromsgrove, Worcestershire, in  and was quickly identied a a rising star. The former City banker sat on the work and Pensions Select Committee, then the powerful Public Accounts Committee. Mr Javid, who comes from a Muslim background but does not practise any religion, was particularly close to Chancellor George Osborne and was appointed a Treasury Minister in September . He was elevated to the Cabinet as Culture Secretary in April of that year and became Business Secretary in May  after the Toriesapos shock election outright victory. He had a picture of Margaret Thatcher hanging on his wall at University. Defence Secretary: Ben Wallace  VOTED REMAIN Ben Wallace gets a promotion from Security Minister to the top job at the Ministry of Defence. Heaposs a married father of three and has been MP for Wyre and Preston North since May . According to his website, his first job after leaving school at  was as a ski instructor in Austria. He went on to enter Royal Military Academy at Sandhurst and was commissioned into the Scots Guards aged . Heaposs also worked in the Aerospace industry. In his spare time, he enjoys rugby, skiing and horse racing. Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster: Michael Gove VOTED LEAVE Johnsonaposs former leadership rival - and the man who infamously torpedoed his last run at being Prime Minister - is back in the fold. Heaposll be Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster and Cabinet Office minister. But unlike his predecessor David Lidington, he wonapost be de facto Deputy PM. That job goes to Dominic Raab. Itaposll be a welcome change of pace for the former journalist, who has spent the last few years at DEFRA banning things. International Trade Secretary: Liz Truss VOTED REMAINLiz Truss has been moved to replace Liam Fox at the Department of International Trade. Sheaposs previously served as Environment Secretary, Justice Secretary and most recently Chief Secretary to the Treasury. Considering her passion for opening new pork markets and for ensuring the success of British cheese, sheaposll fit right in at DIT. Communities Secretary: Robert Jenrick Promoted from a junior Treasury role, Jenrick becomes the youngest member of Johnson Cabinet and one of the youngest in any Cabinet in recent years. He was elected to Parliament in a  by-election in Newark, Notts, triggered by the resignation of Patrick Mercer. Jenrick edited his student newspaper at Cambridge, and went on to become a solicitor, advising businesses and financial institutions on corporate law in London and Moscow, before quitting the profession and moving into business, before switching again, this time into politics. He has three young daughters with we Michal. Justice Secretary: Robert Buckland VOTED REMAIN Robert Buckland has been promoted from Prisons Minister to Johnsonaposs top man in the Ministry of Justice. Buckland is a qualied Barrister and one of the few Remainers left in the cabinet after todayaposs cull. He previously served as Solicitor General from -. Northern Ireland Secretary: Julian Smith VOTED REMAIN Theresa Mayaposs Chief Whip has been sent to possibly the least desirable job in the British Government. Heaposll be in charge of restoring power sharing to Northern Ireland. And then thereaposs the thorny question of finding a way to make the border work with neither a backstop or customs checkpoints. Minister without Portfolio and Conservative Party Chairman: James Cleverly VOTED LEAVE Former Army reservist James Cleverly gets bumped up from junior Brexit minister to Party chairman. Prior to Theresa Mayaposs last reshuffle, he was a deputy Party chair. After briefly standing in the leadership election, he shelved his own ambitions and became a loyal backer of Johnson through the rest of the campaign. Home Office Minister: Brandon Lewis VOTED LEAVE Brandon Lewis gets a ministerial role after  months as Chairman. His tenure as Party chief started out fairly badly. He faced calls for his resignation after it emerged security holes in the Tory Conference app had exposed the private mobile phone numbers of several senior minister to the internet. But it ended on a more positive note, having overseen a broadly successful leadership campaign. SACKED: Dumped from the Cabinet Foreign Secretary: Jeremy Hunt  In the most eye-popping move of the day, Johnsonaposs former leadership rival will be leaving Government entirely. Johnson sacked him as Foreign Secretary and he turned down another job. He tweeted: I would have been honoured to carry on my work at the Foreign Office but understand the need for a new Prime Minister to choose his team. Boris Johnson kindly offered me another role but after nine years in Cabinet  over  cabinet meetings now is the time toto the backbenches from where PM will have my full support. Iaposve been a cabinet minister for every hour my three gorgeous children have been alive. So whilst it may seem strange for someone who just tried to become PMI have decided now is the time for the biggest challenge of all - to be a GOOD DAD! It has been a huge honour to be responsible for the finest diplomatic service in the world  to see the courage  wisdom of our diplomats  intelligence services. Thanks for guiding me with such patience  professionalism! Proud to have stood up alongside you for British values. Also most importantly heartfelt thanks to the   of Conservative Party members who supported me. Despite being the outsider, the #HastobeHunt campaign was spirited  smart . I was truly humbled with the confidence placed in me by so many people. Defence Secretary and Women and Equalities Minister: Penny Mordaunt Defence Secretary Penny Mordaunt, who was made the first woman to hold the office after Gavin Williamson was sacked by Theresa May, has announced she will be ing to the backbenches. She said on Twitter: I’m heading to the backbenches from where the PM will have my full support, as will my successors at DefenceHQ  WomenEqualities. Thank you to everyone who’s helped me get things done, especially our Armed Forces and civilians in defence for the last  days. We achieved much. Itaposs currently unclearshe resigned or was sacked. International Trade Secretary: Liam Fox Liam Fox announced he would not be ing to Government, but he too failed to say whether it was by his choice or Johnsonaposs. He tweeted: Sadly, I will be leaving the Government. It has been a privilege to have served as Secretary of State for International Trade these past  years. I am proud to have worked with a tremendously talented team @tradegovuk to boost trade  investment and prepare for Brexit. The world-class trade department we have built leaves the UK uniquely well-positioned to forge our new trading relationships beyond Europe and create a truly Global Britain. But we must first undertake the momentous task of delivering on the instruction of the British people and leave the European Union. I look forward to supporting @BorisJohnson and the government from the backbenches. Business Secretary: Greg Clark Greg Clark more or less said he had been sacked in a statement issued on Twitter. He wrote: I warmly congratulate Boris Johnson on becoming Prime Minister. He is right to appoint a new team for a new premiership and I wish him and them well for the vital work ahead. It has been an honour to serve the country as Secretary of State for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy for the last  years and as Communities Secretary, Universities amp Science Minister, Cities Minister, Financial Secretary to the Treasury  Planning Minister. I am grateful for the support of outstanding civil servants, special advisors and ministerial colleagues during that time. I look forward to participating fully in the work of Parliament and continuing to serve the people of Tunbridge Wells. Education Secretary: Damian Hinds Education Secretary Damian Hinds has also departed from Boris Johnsonaposs cabinet. He said: It has been the greatest privilege to serve as Education Secretary. Thank you to the brilliant team at @educationgovuk. And thank you to everyone working in education and childrenaposs care, for all you do. I look forward to supporting the government from the backbenches. Communities Secretary: James Brokenshire Despite backing Johnson in the leadership contest, James Brokenshire is out of the Cabinet. His last act in office was to reinstate sacked aposphilosopherapos Roger Scruton to his government advisory role. Northern Ireland Secretary: Karen Bradley  Karen Bradley is reportedly out as Northern Ireland Secretary. Sheaposll perhaps be best remembered for admitting in public that she was profoundly ignorant of Northern Irelandaposs political isions. In an interview with the House Magazine, she said: I freely admit that when I started this job, I didn’t understand some of the deep-seated and deep-rooted issues that there are in Northern Ireland. Scotland Secretary: David Mundell Mundell says he was disappointed, but not surprised to be leaving the Scotland office. Thataposs him sacked then. He tweeted: Disappointed but not surprised to be leaving the Scotland Office after  years. Will, of course, support the new Government, but as I said to PM this afternoon I will also hold him to account on his commitments to the Union. Hope there’s still room on the backbenches! Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Secretary: Jeremy Wright  Mr Wright, who never really seemed comfortable at the ministry of fun, is reportedly gone. Of course, weaposll never know for sure, because the ex-Digital minister is still not on Twitter. Immigration Minister : Caroline Nokes Ms Nokes was reportedly sacked as Immigration Minister. Her tweet announcing the news of her departure contains some brutal shade: My successor as Immigration Minister undoubtedly has a massive challenge ahead. Leader of the House of Commons: Mel Stride Mel Stride was Leader of the House for  days. Barely enough time to get comfortable before heading back to the Backbenches. He wrote: Huge honour to have served as Lord President and Leader of the House. Looking forward to continuing to support my constituents and our PM from backbenches. Huge thanks to all who supported me so brilliantly during my  yrs in govt - in the whips office, HMT and in Leader’s Office NO CHANGE Health Secretary: Matt Hancock VOTED REMAIN The only Health Secretary ever to have his own app is staying in charge of the NHS. The tech-obsessed MP, who once launched his own app, pulled out of the contest to replace Theresa May after he came sixth in the first round of MPs votes. The geeky son of software developers voted Remain in the Brexit referendum but has since backed Brexit. His achievements in government have been limited, with him finally settling the pay dispute with NHS staff negotiated by Jeremy Hunt his only real achievement. But in one of Westminsteraposs most precarious Cabinet jobs sometimes no news can be seen as good news. At just -years-old the former economist, who worked for both George Osborne and the Bank of England, is seen by more moderate Tories as a potential future leader. If he can survive unscathed, and untainted, by Boris Johnsonaposs government. Brexit Secretary: Stephen Barclay VOTED LEAVE Stephen Barclay has been rewarded for failing to secure a Brexit deal that MPs could back under Theresa May by being allowed to keep his job as Brexit Secretary. Stephen Barclay was appointed by Theresa May after both previous holders of the job - David Davis and Dominic Raab - quit over her plans for Brexit . Barclay - who calls himself Steve - is the -year-old MP for North East Cambridgeshire. The former Axa insurance lawyer and dad-of-two was born in , the son of a union official and civil servant, and grew up with three brothers who all played rugby. Work and Pensions Secretary: Amber Rudd VOTED REMAIN Amber Rudd has been rewarded for her latter-day conversion to accepting no-deal Brexit as an option by being allowed to keep her job. Sheaposs also been made Women and Equalities Minister, which was previously part of departing Defence Secretary Penny Mordauntaposs job. After backing the Remain campaign at the referendum, she said last week: The situation is that we are leaving at the end of October but it would be so much better to get a deal. What we really need is for everybody’s effort to go into trying to get a deal. Wales Secretary: Alun Cairns Alun Cairns has been Secretary of State for Wales since March , and Boris Johnson doesnapost see why he should stop now. He has run the London Marathon seven times. His personal best is h m s, making him the seventh fastest MP ever. CRACKED: Resigned from Cabinet Deputy PM: David Lidington  Theresa Mayaposs deputy David Lidington, the Cabinet Office minister, announced he was stepping down - and suggested heaposll now fight No Deal. The ardently pro-EU MP said he was relishing the chance to campaign freely on issues close to his heart. He wrote: After  yrs on the front bench itaposs the right moment to move on. I shall leave the govt when Theresa May offers her resignation to The Queen. I shall do all I can to help new govt secure a deal to allow an orderly departure from the EU. After more than two decades of collective responsibility Iaposm now relishing the prospect of speaking  campaigning freely for the things that matter to me  to my constituents. Chancellor: Philip Hammond  Philip Hammond confirmed he was getting ready to quit ahead of Boris Johnson taking over as PM. The Chancellor is vehemently opposed to crashing out of the UK without a deal. He said he wouldnapost wait to be sacked by Boris Johnson but rather planned to resign after Theresa Mayaposs last PMQs in place on Wednesday. In his resignation letterhe said: I believe that your successor must be free to choose a Chancellor who is fully aligned with his policy position.  Justice Secretary David Gauke served in Theresa Mayaposs Cabinet since she took office in June . He was so famed for his cool manner that he used to get uncorked by more senior Tories to face dficult questions. But he said he would not be able to serve under Boris Johnson. Given that Iaposve been in the Cabinet since Theresa May came to power, I think the appropriate thing is for me to resign to her, he said. Heaposs now tipped to form a Gaukeward Squad on the backbenches fighting against a No Deal Brexit . OUT: Sir Mick Davis  Tory Party Treasurer and chief executive Sir Mick Davis said he was on the way out. Once a new leader has been selected by either a General Election or a party vote, the Queen has the job of officially asking themthey will form a Governmen t. Sheaposs worked with some real characters over the years, including Winston Churchill, Margaret Thatcher and John Major. The Queen isnapost allowed to share her political views and never speaks about her relationships with the leaders, but there have been a few interesting reports. The Royal Familyaposs official website says the Monarch always has a aposspecial relationshipapos with whoever is leading her Government - so weaposve had a look back at some of the more interesting ones...   Margaret Thatcher The Queen and Mrs Thatcher apparently didnapost really get on.    In fact, a Buckingham Palace source told a diplomat the monarch actually considered scrapping their weekly meetings all together. Declassied files revealed in  claimed the Tory PM enraged the Queen by defying Commonwealth leaders in a vote over apartheid . Files from the National Archives of Ireland show that Thatcher sparked international anger after refusing to back tighter sanctions against South Africa. The move had been agreed by  leaders at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Vancouver, Canada, but Mrs Thatcher refused, thwarting efforts to end apartheid and enraging heads of state.    An Irish diplomat based in London reported back to Dublin that it was widely regarded that the PM had “blundered badly” and “she well knows but cannot admit her mistake”. After speaking with a source at Buckingham Palace, he sent a confidential message to the Taoiseach’s office. The diplomat wrote: “There is a wide view too that the Queen is in a rage with Mrs Thatcher over her handling of the sanctions .” Using the nickname Brenda, which was given to the Queen by satirical magazine Private Eye, the diplomat continued: “A source in the palace said that ‘Brenda’ was seriously considering cancelling last night’s Tuesday audience with the prime minister. This audience... has existed for more than a century.” Winston Churchill Churchill was the first PM the Queen worked with after her fatheraposs early and tragic death. They were reportedly very close, and he was said to be a formidable presence for the young monarch, who was just  at the time. Nicholas Soames, Churchillaposs grandson, said: I think the Queen valued my grandfatheraposs experience, and he of course loved the Queen. He did love her.    I mean, she aroused in him all his romantic ideas of sovereignty and monarchy. Royal historian Robert Lacey added: I think there’s a sense in which all the Queen’s Prime Ministers have been in love with her to a certain degree. But it was most overtly displayed by Churchill. He made no pretence at it, there were tears in his eyes when he welcomed her. The Queen send Churchill a handwritten letter after he retired in  saying how much she missed him She  wrote that no other PM would would ever for me be able to hold the place of my first prime minister, to whom both my husband and I owe so much and for whose wise guidance during the early years of my reign I shall always be so profoundly grateful.    After Churchillaposs death in  she broke royal protocol by arriving at his funeral before his family did. The Queen is supposed to be the last person to arrive at any official occasion - including a State Funeral - but the Monarch decided to get there before his grieving relatives. Nicholas explained what the Queen’s gesture meant to his family in the TV show. He said: It is absolutely exceptionalnot unique for the Queen to grant precedence to anyone. For her to arrive before the coffin and before my grandfather was a beautul and very touching gesture. Tony Blair Tony Blair has spoken on a number of occasions about how he felt he could tell the Queen absolutely anything, knowing it would never go any further. In an interview with the BBC he said: There is nothing you canapost say to the Queen. Speaking for a  documentary called aposMonarchy: The Royal Family at Workapos, he said: I’ve told her about lots of things in my time.    You know, everything from Cherie being pregnant with Leo through to, you know, major decisions. Because the one thing you know is that she will never ulge anything to anyone. However in his  book Comparative Politics: A Policy Approach foreign affairs writer Michael J Kryzanek said he believed the Queen and Blairaposs audiences probably were perfunctory. He said: Although Mr Blair’s reform of the aristocratic Lords and his Labour  Party’s traditional public criticism of the monarchy would likely mean that the weekly discussion between the two is perfunctory.    In  Labouraposs Tony Blair was slammed for snubbing the Queen’s Diamond Jubilee celebrations to sun himself in the Males. The ex-Prime Minister was invited to pay his respects in person but instead went for a holiday and sent a video tribute. Tory MP Priti Patel said: “He should be ashamed of himself. He spends a huge amount of time ­gallivanting round the world.” Buckingham Palace said: “There would have been no offence taken.” Anthony Eden Things were more formal between the Queen and Anthony Eden, who took over from Churchill. However it is reported that at one of their audiences they stayed clear of political chat and instead just listened as US astronaut John Glenn went into space on the radio.  Alec Douglas-Home The Queen reportedly spoke to Douglas-Home like an old friend, discussing dogs and going shooting together. Harold Wilson The Queen reportedly used to invite the Labour MP to join the Royals for picnics in Balmoral.  James Callaghan Mr Callaghan once said of the Queen: One of the great things about her is that she always seems able to see the funny side of le. All the conversations were very enjoyable. Sir John Major Major was well liked by the Royal Family as he has shown a deeply care for Princes William and Harry. After Dianaaposs death in  he was appointed specialto Princes Harry and William, and was responsible for legal and administrative matters.  Major, whose appointment was reported to have been made at the suggestion of Prince Charles, was asked to protect the interests of Harry and William in negotiations over their mother’s will. Lawyers for Sir John even went to court to seek powers to protect the princesapos financial interest in souvenirs and memorabilia related to their late mother the Princess of Wales. He was the only politician to be invited to Meghan Markle and Prince Harryaposs Royal Wedding last year.  Kensington Palace sources stressed in the run up to the wedding that those at the ceremony would be picked due to their relationship with the couple rather than the positions they hold. Along with former death penalty supporter Priti Pateland Thatcherite former banker Sajid Javid , his promotion marks a clean sweep of right-wingers in the great offices of state.So who is the MP, and why has he stirred controversy  He sparked fury in  by saying most food bank users are not languishing in poverty. When a disability activist told him people are dying under Tory austerity, he described her calls for cash as a childish wish list. He branded feminists obnoxious bigots. And he put out a pamphlet in  that suggested exempting small firms from minimum wage laws for workers under . Hereaposs a profile - and  things you should probably know.  Former grammar school boy Mr Raab, now , was born to a Czech Jewish father who fled to Britain as a refugee before the Second World War. The Oxford and Cambridge graduate was a City lawyer with Linklaters before joining the Foreign Office in , helping bring war criminals to justice in The Hague. He once found himself defending Tony Blair from being summoned to the international criminal court while working on the trial of Slobodan Milosevic. He left the civil service for hard politics in  becoming chief of staff to Tory shadow home secretary David Davis. He was elected MP for Esher and Walton in  and joined government in , quickly rising through the ranks. During his time as a junior minister in the Ministry of Justice, Mr Raab tried to get prisoners with sentences of longer than a year deported. He also led debates against a European Court of Justice decision giving at least some prisoners the right to vote. In July  he replaced David Davis as Brexit Secretary - probably the most crucial and stressful job in government. But he lasted just five months in the role, resigning in November  in protest of Theresa Mayaposs Brexit deal.   He stepped down just hours after Theresa May published her -page Brexit deal, accusing the Prime Minister of betraying public trust. He later ran for the Tory leadershipbut lent his support to Boris Johnson when he was knocked out. He lives in Thames Ditton, Surrey, with his we Erika and two sons Peter and Joshua and his heroes include right-wing US President Ronald Reagan and Gandhi.  Mr Raab is a hardliner who wants to take a aposstrongmanapos approach to the EU - and was willing to crash out in a No Deal Brexit on October he had become Tory leader. He backed Brexit before the  EU referendum and was on the political advisory board of Leave Means Leave - which branded Theresa Mayaposs plans fake Brexit and a total, humiliating capitulation. He previously said he was relaxed about the prospect of crashing out of the EU with no deal. And after declaring his leadership bid, he confirmed: I would fight for a fairer deal in Brussels with negotiations to change the backstop arrangements. If not I would be clear that we would leave on WTO terms in October. We need to go out and be absolutely resolute in the way we werenapost last time. aposWTO termsapos are the harshest trading terms with another country - the basic default. Theyaposre a No Deal Brexit. Chancellor Philip Hammond refused to rule out voting no-confidence in a Tory government that went for a No Deal Brexit.  As a Tory leadership candidate, Mr Raab even refused to rule out some kind of pact with Nigel Farageaposs Brexit Party.  He stressed thereaposd be no formal coalition but stopped well short of ruling out co-operation entirely. Askedhe could do business with Mr Farage, the former minister said: Look, I always listen to all sides of this debate, from Nigel Farage to others. But no, I would lead a Conservative team, uniting all the dferent aspects of the Conservative Party around a cabinet table. When askedas leader he would enter an electoral pledge with Mr Farage, he said he had no plans for that. He added: Thataposs not what I would be aiming for. My aim is not to cosy up with other parties, my aim is to keep Conservative promises, present an optimistic, aspirational vision of the future, then go and beat Jeremy Corbyn .  Nine years of cruel Tory austerity cuts slashed services to the bone while failing to wipe out the deficit by , as ministers had promised. Yet it seems Dominic Raab once again was looking at this approach as a leadership candidate - not to balance the books this time, but to give people a huge tax cut. He wants to reduce the basic rate of income tax from p to p over time - including a p drop straight away - and lower national insurance by raising the threshold. Mr Raab claimed there was £bn of headroom in the public finances to make the move. But he also admitted itaposd involve slashing back government through efficiency savings - a front often used for cuts in David Cameronaposs era. He told the BBC: We would have a spending review... cut down the number of Whitehall departments, cut out the bureaucracy, Iaposd have a special commission looking at public sector procurement particularly in the NHS and MOD. Then I would recycle roughly half of that into frontline services - teachers, schools, nurses - and half of that into the tax cuts for the future.  At the time Dominic Raab was Brexit Secretary when he revealed he aposhadnapost understoodapos the importance of trade with France. Seventeen per cent of the UK’s trade in goods, or £ billion annually, goes through Dover to either Calais or Dunkirk, according to port officials.  But speaking at a London tech event, Mr Raab said: “I hadn’t quite understood the full extent of this, butyou look at the UK and you look at how we trade in goods, we are particularly reliant on the Dover-Calais crossing. . And he didnapost read the full Good Friday Agreement either He also admitted he hadnapost read the Good Friday Agreement - crucial to peace in Northern Ireland - start to finish. At ious points in the negotiations, when issues have been raised, it has been an important opportunity to delve into the dferent aspects very carefully, he told MPs. “It’s not like a novel where you sit down and you say ‘do you know what, over the holidays, this is a cracking read’. . Heaposs raised the idea of a Brexit tax haven  Dominic Raab raised the prospect of a radical corporation tax cut from % to % in a No Deal Brexit. This would make the rate the lowest in the G by a country mile - handing global firms a huge tax break while millions of working families struggle. He made the bombshell suggestion on the fringes of the  Tory conference in a discussion about No Deal, while he was Brexit Secretary. Mr Raab was asked his view on an idea by Chloe Westley, of the right-wing TaxPayers Alliance think tank, of dropping corporation tax to % - and using tax to get a “post-Brexit boom”. The then-Cabinet minister replied: “You just said Chloe wants to reduce corporation tax to % - and the Chancelloraposs talked about reserving fiscal firepower in the case of no deal. What more do you want  “Of course heaposs talking about the recognition that actually, in the no deal scenario, we want to pull every lever weaposve got to see us through what short term buffeting or disruption we have. “I think the Chancellor gave a brilliant speech and it shows you weaposre all rowing the same boat.”  Mr Raab sparked fury in  by saying most food bank users are not languishing in poverty - even though benefit delays and sanctions are the main reason for people using the handouts. He claimed: The typical user of a foodbank is not someone thataposs languishing in poverty, itaposs someone who has a cash flow problem episodically.  . He branded calls for NHS cash a aposchildish wish listapos When a disability activist told him people are dying under Tory austerity, he dismissed her calls for cash as a childish wish list. He told an election debate in : The money’s got to come from somewhere. I can think of lots of things that I would like to avoid making dficult decisions on and lots of areas like the health service or schools that I want to put even more money in. But unless you’ve got a strong economy creating the revenue, it’s just a childish wish list. . He had some worrying views on workersapos rights  Mr Raab has some worrying views on workersapos rights, including scaling back the minimum wage. He put forward proposals in a pamphlet published by the Centre for Policy Studies in  entitled aposEscaping the Strait Jacketapos. Raabaposs pamphlet included proposals to:Abolish the minimum wage for workers aged under  working in small businesses Abolish the working time directive which protects workers from having to work unfair hours Scrap employment rights for agency workers’ rights and conditions End transfer of undertakingsregulations protecting workers when their job is transferred to a new employer Ensure workers employed by small businesses donapost benefit from flexible working rights or pension auto-enrolment. He branded feminists aposobnoxious bigotsapos In  Mr Raab said feminists are now amongst the most obnoxious bigots and said it was time for men to start burning their briefs. He defended the remarks in . He had written: While we have some of the toughest anti-discrimination laws in the world, we are blind to some of the most flagrant discrimination – against men. From the cradle to the grave, men are getting a raw deal. . He was in a Facebook group calling for NHS privatisation In February , BuzzFeed revealed he belonged to a Facebook group which argued for all of Britain’s council housing to be sold off and the NHS to be privatised. Mr Raab said he wasnapost aware of the group, had inadvertently and mistakenly been linked to it and needless to say I do not support its aims.” . He branded Brits aposthe worst idlers in the worldapos  In , Mr Raab was one of five Tory MPs who branded Britons “the worst idlers in the world”. Their book argued: “Too many people in Britain, we argue, prefer a lie-in to hard work. We must get on the side of the responsible, the hard working and the brave. We must stop bailing out the reckless, avoiding all risk, and rewarding laziness. Once they enter the workplace, the British are among the worst idlers in the world. We work among the lowest hours, we retire early and our productivity is poor.” . He got embroiled in a row about housing stats  In April , Mr Raab was embroiled in an embarrassing row with the official statistics watchdog after he claimed immigration has made house prices soar. The Tory minister dramatically declared migration has made prices rise something like % over the last  years. But the statistics he used were not public - and it was claimed the body that drew them up has not even existed since . Ed Humpherson, Head of the UK Statistics Authority’s Office for Statistics Regulation said: “Where analysis is quoted in public debate, the UK Statistics Authority believes it is essential that it be made equally available to all. “We have been speaking to officials at the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government about the Minister’s statements on migration and housing.” . He revealed he had faced a claim of bullying, which he added was aposapos and aposunsubstantiatedapos Mr Raab attempted to outflank hostile rumours in March  by confirming he had faced an accusation of bullying in a previous job. He told The Sunday Times the claims, which date back to before he was an MP, were completely ”. Mr Raab worked for then-shadow ministers David Davis and Dominic Grieve in the years before becoming an MP in . He said: “In , in a previous role before I became an MP, I was subject to a claim of bullying. I vigorously denied the claims, which were independently investigated and found to be unsubstantiated. The claim that I secured an injunction or any kind of ‘gagging’ order is .” . And of course, thereaposs his diary secretary - with her clams about his lunch Mr Raab also shot into headlines after a Mirror investigation exposed his diary secretary selling sex online. He denied her claims that he had exactly the same Pret a Manger lunch each day - a chicken Caesar and bacon baguette, superfruit pot and the vitamin volcano smoothie. “He is so weird. I get it for him. I go to Pret. That’s how I know. It’s the Dom Raab Special, the diary secretary said. Mr Raab said: Itaposs not actually true.

title: workers stay cool under new
story: NewsWorkers to stay cool under new maximum workplace temperature pledgeLabour plans to introduce measures to prevent employees from working in unbearable heatShareCommentsByMatthew Dresch:,  JUL NewsThe plan has been announced at the same time as a searing heatwave hits the UK "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour has unveiled a new plan to keep workers cool during high temperatures. The scheme is being announced today - on what is expected to be the hottest July day on record, with temperatures hitting C. The ‘maximum workplace temperature’ rule will protect workers and force bosses to introduce effective heat controls. Most workers in the UK have no legal safeguards protecting them from working during uncomfortably high temperatures or dangerous extreme heat.    The current guidance states a minimum working temperature but does not include an upper limit.Under Labour ’s plan: If the indoor workplace temperature goes over C , employers will have to put in place effective temperature controls to help workers keep cool. These would include measures that many good employers already take: flexible working and travel arrangements, extra breaks, access to water, cooling systems air conditioning, flexible dress codes or the provision of protective clothing. Labour will task a proposed Royal Commission on Health and Safety at Work with bringing forward realistic proposals to protect all workers – including all outdoor workers - from extreme or uncomfortable temperatures at work.Laura Pidcock MP, Labour’s Shadow Minister for Labour, said: “As we’re all being reminded this week, working in hot conditions is really uncomfortable, often stressful and it makes us less productive and even ill. Plus it’s often the lowest paid and most insecure workers who suffer the most. “That’s why the next Labour government will demand that employers look after the needs of their workers during heatwaves like this. We believe everyone should have the right to basic protections from working in unbearably hot conditions. “Climate change is already making our shops, offices, call-centres and other workplaces too hot, and it’s also threatening the safety and health of old people, babies and many others.

title: abandoned arcade on dundees reform street to be reborn as series of retail units
story: A long-abandoned arcade in Dundee city centre is set to be reborn as a series of retail units, pending approval by city planners.Hynds Amusement Arcade was snapped up by local property firm West One Property in January for a reported £,.West One has now submitted its redevelopment plan to Dundee City Council for review, with a decision expected in September.Lee Chadwick, director of the firm, wants to ide the large space into three retail units to attract new tenants.He said: “We hope to seek approval to split the building into three normal-sized units.“The unit currently is too large – it is laid out to maximise floorspace which is useful for an arcade.“By splitting the units it opens up the property to multiple uses. It will also keep business rates at a sensible level, at no loss to the council. This will benefit Reform Street and the city centre.”The application by West One, based in the city’s Blinshall Street, is the first by any party to bring the amusement arcade back into use.But the plan comes hot on the heels of a blip in confidence among business owners on Reform Street, who spoken of its “second album syndrome” following a resurgence in food outlets that began with Project Pizza in .The eatery, initially hailed as the shape of things to come, closed without warning last month and the unit is now advertised for let.Proprietors such as Akky Hayat – who runs German Doner Kebab and Fatburger – say punitive business rates are discouraging others from opening shops on the street.Mr Chadwick has not been discouraged. He added: “Footfall is rising and there are positive steps in the regeneration of the area.“The demise of Project Pizza is a minor setback to a street that is on the up.”However, it is hard to ignore the units once home to Victoria Wine, TSB and Swinton Insurance, which have remained conspicuously empty long after they have closed.

title: aberdeen slash away fan ticket allocation at pittodrie unacceptable conduct
story: Aberdeen have slashed the allocation for away fans at Pittodrie for next season following discussions with Police Scotland.The move comes in reaction to a number of recent #incidents of unacceptable conduct#.The allocation for visiting fans will be slashed from , to , for next season with a segregation banner placed between Aberdeen and away fans.Police Scotland launched an investigation into an incident where seats were thrown by both home and away supporters in the - Scottish Cup quarter final draw with Rangers at Pittodrie in March.In a club statement the Dons, who are out in Georgia on Europa League duty, admit they will take a financial hit in slashing more than  tickets.However, they are ready to take lose that cash to ensure the safety of supporters.Aberdeen have also invested in new state of the art CCTV to identy any iniduals who commit acts of unacceptable conduct.The Dons confirmed that #unacceptable conduct# includes the #singing of songs that could be construed as being of an offensive or inflammatory nature and which have no place in Scottish football#.A club statement said: “Following an increase in the number of incidents of unacceptable conduct within Scottish football last season, Aberdeen FC has today announced its plans for the coming season, designed to ensure the Pittodrie matchday experience is one that can be undergone in as safe and enjoyable environment as possible for all supporters.“As a consequence of the review, undertaken in conjunction with Police Scotland and the Sports Ground Advisory Working Group, the South Stand segregation area currently used in lower category games will now be in place during all categories of games.“A total of , tickets will subsequently be available in the away section.“A segregation banner will be utilised in the middle of section R and will be stewarded and policed accordingly.“This ensures that at all games there is an enhanced area between the two sets of supporters.”Rangers fans were allocated , tickets for the quarter-final clash last season.It is the second time in recent years the Dons have cut ticket allocation available to away fans.Previously travelling supporters, primarily Celtic and Rangers, would be given , briefs, but that was halved.Following further talks with police and other authorities, the away allocation has dropped again and the club will erect a new safety zone which will leave more than  seats out of commission.The statement continued: “While this move will inevitably result in a financial penalty for the club as fewer seats will be available to visiting supporters, AFC believes the safety of all fans is absolutely paramount and the overriding factor in this instance.“The club has also invested signicantly in new state-of-the-art CCTV that has the technology to identy iniduals who commit acts of unacceptable conduct or which could be perceived as being unacceptable conduct.“Unacceptable conduct includes the singing of songs that could be construed as being of an offensive or inflammatory nature and which have no place in Scottish football.“The ultimate aim is to enhance the wider matchday experience and ensure that supporters of all ages enjoy their time at Pittodrie.“Any supporters who witness instances of unacceptable conduct can contact the ‘Tackle Textline’ on   in the strictest confidence.”

story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Further to your article #Three amigos clean up in Lochgilphead#, Friday May , I would like to add the lane behind Lochgilphead Bowling Club is often filled with fresh poo.I#m sick of coming over nearly every day and finding poo all over the lane. The lane floods, so between trying to dodge puddles, you land in dog dirt.I wish they would fix the path because a lot of people use it, some of them pensioners with or parents with prams.Celia MacFarlane, Lochgilphead.Sir,Seven out of ten people with diabetes feel overwhelmed by the demands of their condition and this signicantly affects their mental and physical health.That is why we are calling for new national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health support and to increase support available in Argyll to people living with diabetes.As part of Diabetes UK’s Diabetes Weekwe are urging people in Argyll to #SeeDiabetesDferently and back our campaign for national standards for diabetes mental health support and services.Our recently published research revealed the relentless nature of diabetes can impact people’s emotional well-being and mental health, ranging from day-to-day frustration and low mood, to specic psychological and mental health dficulties including clinical depression and anxiety.The findings, published in the report #Too often missing: Making emotional and psychological support routine in diabetes care#, show that diabetes is much more than a physical condition – and that emotional and psychological demands of living with diabetes should be recognised and support provided.Diabetes Scotland is urgently calling on the NHS to create national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health services. These should ensure everyone receives #joined up# care, that they are asked how they are feeling as part of every diabetes appointment and that a mental health professional with knowledge of diabetes is part of every diabetes care team.To sign our petition, go to diabetes.org.uk missingAngela Mitchell, National Director of Diabetes Scotland.Sir,I#m asking residents in the Highlands and Islands to give their views on Conservative proposals for tackling serious crime.In order to provide Scotland with an alternative to Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP in , we are keen to gain feedback from as many people to our policy proposals to make them as relevant as possible to the needs and aspirations of everyone in Scotland.Too many people in Scotland are affected by the behaviour of serious criminals. This needs to be properly addressed and my colleague Liam Kerr MSP, shadow Justice Secretary, has outlined key policy proposals in a member#s bill in the Scottish Parliament to tackle this scourge.It would give Scottish judges the power to impose whole le sentences to those convicted of the most serious violent and sexual crimes including the murder of a police officer.The courts would still have discretion to impose the appropriate sentence based on all the facts of each case, as they do in England and Wales where such a provision already exists.The proposed Whole Le CustodyBill will not mean the perpetrators of a particular crime will always receive a whole le sentence, but rather that the courts will have the power to impose one where there is sufficient justication.We have started the consultation and experts and members of the public are invited to register their views.Email me at donald.cameron.msp@parliament.scot or write to me at Donald Cameron MSP,  George Street, Oban, PA NT, with your views.MSP Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands.Sir,The SNP has warned Scotland’s NHS is under threat from a Tory-Trump trade deal that could leave the Scottish Government without a veto over a post-Brexit deal that sells Scotland out.This stark warning follows the revelations from Donald Trump that in terms of trade deals, everything, including the NHS, would be on the table.At Prime Ministers Questions, SNP Deputy Westminster Leader Kirsty Blackman MP said Donald Trump and the Tories could not be trusted on the NHS and criticised the UK government for plotting to take powers away from the Scottish Parliament that would allow it to safeguard Scotland’s NHS.The threats to Scotland#s NHS are growing under the prospect of a hard-right Tory-Trump Brexit trade deal. Those threats could undermine the integrity and independence of our Scottish NHS.The UK Tories will block any potential veto by the Scottish Government over such a damaging deal.The SNP government will fight to the end to defend Scotland#s public services from this unprecedented Tory Brexit danger. Our NHS must remain in public hands. It is not, and should never be, up for sale.Scotland has been completely ignored throughout the Brexit process and Tory plans to grab powers from the Scottish Parliament will leave us even more exposed.It is clearer than ever that the only way to properly protect Scotland#s interests, and keep our NHS in public hands, is with the full powers of independence.MP Brendan O#Hara, Argyll and Bute.

title: racing buzz returns to famous kilmartin circuit
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThere was a palpable air of excitement in the air as racing ed to Kilmartin.The course, in the shadow of Carnasserie Castle and newly reclaimed from a dense layer of bracken, lived up to its reputation as a true championship test.The course # home to the only ever Scottish round of the GP World Motocross Championship in June  # played host to round five of the  Scottish Twin Shock championship in the first race to have been held there in decades.The track itself is  natural undulating land and not a man-made track, described by racing aficionados as a place for #vintage scrambling motocross#.Hot and dry weather in the week leading up to the event on Saturday June  was interrupted by a shower on race morning and this, combined with cut vegetation on the track, made for interesting conditions early in proceedings # which simply added to the excitement.Ricky Caldwell, chairman of the Scottish Twin Shock Scramble Club, said: #The sighting laps caused a little bit of a hold at the bottom of the hills due to the rain which had fallen which made a couple of the hills very slippery at the start of the day.#A few riders had not realised this and had a little sit down on them to gather their thoughts and then have another go. Once we got the racing underway everything flowed along very well indeed and there was some fantastic racing for all to watch.#He added: #Everyone connected with the club had an absolute awesome weekend at Kilmartin, and the place was buzzing.#It was especially great to see such a large number of spectators who made the effort to come along to watch, and after speaking to a few of them they seemed to have enjoyed themselves as much as we did .#Special mention and thanks must go to Jonathan McLeod who was the driving force behind this event, and without his enthusiasm and effort this would not have happened.#We also need to thank the three unsung local workers Ronnie, Jamie and Johnny ,who along with Jonathan all put a tremendous amount of work into the track over the last couple of weeks, cutting down all the bracken by hand on the hill areas, cutting grass and all round general work to ensure this race meet went ahead.#Ricky Caldwell concluded: #The riders are excited about coming back next year # so watch this space.#

It is not clear when the older photograph was taken, but it must have been in the early part of the th century, perhaps nudging into the late th century.The cottages are mostly thatched, while poles on the shore may be stances for drying fishing nets.Why there is a ladder up the tree to the right of the photograph is anyone#s guess.The field in the foreground behind the cottages is likely to have been croft land, but is now built upon with newer homes. Though not taken from the same spot, the image above gives an idea of the more cluttered scene in the st century.

Front line staff are working hard to provide care in very dficult circumstances, but care in the community can only workproperly resourced by senior management.It is hard to avoid the conclusion that many of the decisions to sht care away from centres such as hospitals are as much to do with saving money as the genuine best interest of patients.In times of recession it is, once again, the most vulnerable in society who bear the brunt.The rain is teeming down as this is being written, but last weekend saw sunshine and crowds in Tarbert.The atmosphere was fantastic for the seafood festival, and there is no doubt the weather helped in a big way.Congratulations to the small band of organisers for another great weekend.

title: kilmartin twinshocks race report
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Jim GrieveRace day on the iconic former Grand Prix track at Carnasserie Castle on June  started off on a sombre note, as riders all paid respects with a minute of silence for fallen riding legendary Ian ‘Lugs’ Robertson.Many riders sported Ian’s riding number  on their bikes.The racing started with group one and the flying EVO cc class with Peter O#Neil, and William Penrice showing the bigger bikes how it should be done. Peter O#Neil edged out Penrice in race one, but Penrice would take his revenge in race two and it was all to play for in the final encounter. Peter O#Neil was up to the task and would take the overall, with Penrice a deserved second and  Damian Carter would third.The four stroke class was enthralling, with Sam Sibbald thundering around the Kilmartin track, big Andy Malloch and his Armstrong chasing him all the way to the flag and winning the final race but not the overall. Sam would be the victor followed by Andy and a consistent Keith Stanford third.For the youth class it was a day of mixed fortunes and consistency would be the key, with Jordan Graham coming out on top ahead of James Forrest and picking up a superb third overall was Rhys Brown.Pre- action would see committee man and track builder Grant McClure and his Maico, with three decades of riding under his belt, become the overall winner ahead of Callum Wilson on the superbly prepared Honda.The Twinshock under cc event would be a three race win for the flying Calum Kilgour and his cc Yamaha ahead of Jim Grieve, who would have some bike issues but would bring home his Honda in second fighting off a very persistent David Lawson and Gordon Peterson but it would be Gordon that would hold the third place trophy with some consistent riding.The Twinshock open class event would be a spectacular sight as cc Hondas and Maicos battled their way around the bracken.In race one there was a very small gap between first and second place and a similarly small gap between third. Brian Alexander would take the win from Craig ‘Smitch’ Smith, and John Crawford would come home in third with a notable mention to the very unlucky Paul Chiappa who had his fair share of misfortunes throughout the day, as his seat was torn from his bike at the top of one of the steep climbs. The overall would end up the same as the first race with Brian, taking the win from Craig Smith and John Crawford bringing the big Honda home in third.In the over s class it was a triumphant day for John Lamont with three resounding victories. Johnny Rutherford was second, a great result for the club sponsor, with David Watson bringing home the Honda with some consistent rides.For the group three races Robert Bell took the honours from Allan Shields and Bryan Colligan, all of these riders deserving a notable mention and with some very similar lap times and some quick racing in trying conditions.The clubman class was great to watch, with some fast up-and-coming riders such as Peter Rennie, Callum Laird and Stuart Wilson all angling for the win. Rennie would take the overall from Laird in second and  Wilson in third.The evolution class was again the Paul and Tom show. In what must have been the fastest racing all day, it would be Paul #PJ# Johnston who would take overall honours with three wins and Tom Grant would take the runner-up slot followed home ably by a consistent Roy Potts taking the third place.In the final block of racing it would be a win apiece for Jordan McDonald, Shaun Robertson, and John Kenny, but it would be the ever improving Shaun Robertson, ing from injury, who would take overall honours from a rapidly improving John Kenny in second and #Mr Consistent# Karl Livingstone in third.Results:Group Pre- class:  Grant McClure  Callum Wilson. title: tayvallich celebrates summer in style
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowTayvallich is set for a fortnight of celebration, centred around the annual gala weekend at the end of July.The action kicks off on Thursday July  when Balter, one of the most feted bands on the folk circuit,to the stage at the Village Hall. Balter are a contemporary folk quartet who have emerged from the music scene in Newcastle but are strongly influenced by their shared love of Scottish music.These four multi-talented womenfollow up their success at Glasgow’s Celtic Connections festival and as finalists in the Battle of the Folk Bands in Edinburgh to bring their exuberance and infectious live energy back to Tayvallich after a barnstorming gig there a year ago.Playing music from Shetland, the Borders, the Western Isles and Ireland, from foot-stomping jigs and reels to soulful Gaelic melodies, the foursome combine traditional and original material. The interplay between fiddles, mandolin and accordion creates a distinctive sound of intricate arrangements that mixes Balter’s traditional heritage with contemporary influences.The celebrations continue when the Tayvallich Big Weekend gets under way on Friday July  with a barbeque and live music at the Tayvallich Inn. The focus moves to the village hall on Saturday July .Starting at am, there are games sports stalls from local businesses, voluntary groups and organizations and fabulous food and drink. Pooches both pedigree and potpourri have their day at the ever-popular Dog Show.The Family Ceilidh on Saturday evening has live music from the exhilarating Argyll Ceilidh Trail band. The weekend is rounded off on Sunday morning with the World Crab Fishing Championship on the Tayvallich village pontoon.The party continues on Wednesday July , when gypsy jazz quartet Latchepen roll up. Latchepen are a London-based gypsy jazz outfit comprising four musicians from dferent corners of the globe, brought together by a shared admiration of Django Reinhardt and all that swings. Latchepen is an exclamation of happiness and contentment in the Romani language. Acoustic by nature but with projection and a heartbeat that rival any amp or drum, this is jazz on a string with influences ranging from Romani music to bebob.Fun, games, music, food and drink # Tayvallich is the place to be this month.Balter will rock Tayvallich on Thursday July  at pm before Latchepen gets everyone dancing on Wednesday July  at pm. Tickets are £at the door or email info.tayvhall@gmail.The venue is unlicensed but you are welcome to bring your own bottle.

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowMore than , people went along to soak up the atmosphere at Inveraray Highland Games on a sunny Tuesday July .So too did the Band of Her Majesty’s Royal Marines Scotland, special guests at the games for .Inveraray and District Pipe Band led the traditional march through the royal burgh to the games field at the Winterton the march headed by His Grace the Duke of Argyll.For the first time Archie, Marquess of Lorne, now aged , helped the Duchess to present prizes at the games.As usual the games attracted visitors from all across the world some to complete in the track and field, heavy athletics, solo piping and the dancing, others just to watch the fun.The Clan Campbell Society of Germany members once again hosted their own tent at the games.Inveraray Games is also the home of the World Caber Championships, sponsored by the town’s George Hotel and won this year by Lucaz Wenta of Poland, who now lives in Scotland.The whole world will be able to see Inveraray Games thanks to the Smithsonian Channel, which had a film crew at the games. Full details of the programme and the date it will be broadcast have yet to be announced.
